videoTitle: Improving outcomes in obstructive sleep apnea surgery | UCLA Health
videoDescription: In this webinar, UCLA Health sleep medicine experts dive into improving outcomes in obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) surgery. They highlight the latest advancements and research that can guide better treatment options for patients. Key points covered in this video include: ‚Ä¢ Understanding the mechanisms of OSA and its impact on health ‚Ä¢ Surgical evaluation for OSA and the role of neurostimulation ‚Ä¢ DISE (Drug-Induced Sleep Endoscopy) findings and their influence on surgical outcomes ‚Ä¢ The latest on Inspire Upper Airway Stimulation and its long-term results ‚Ä¢ Endotypic traits and how they affect treatment responses We also explore recent findings on how palate shape and airway obstruction sites can influence the success of surgery, as well as the effectiveness of advanced therapies like Inspire for those who need more than traditional CPAP therapy. Want to learn more? videoTitle: Revolutionizing AML treatment: The future of iNKT cell therapy | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Standard treatments for acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) offer only a 30% survival rate at five years ‚Äî an unacceptable statistic. But at UCLA Health, oncologist Caspian Oliai, MD and his team are pioneering a groundbreaking alternative: Chimeric antigen receptor iNKT cell therapy. This innovative immunotherapy harnesses a healthy donor's immune system to fight leukemia, offering a more effective, off-the-shelf solution compared to traditional CAR T-cell therapy. With multiple mechanisms of action and the ability to be administered immediately, iNKT cell therapy could dramatically improve survival rates while reducing costs and eliminating the need for chemotherapy. Backed by research published in leading scientific journals and supported by the state of California, UCLA Health is now ready to launch a clinical trial ‚Äî but we need your support. Join us in making history by funding a life-changing therapy that could transform AML treatment for patients worldwide. To learn more or to make a donation, visit: uclahealth.org/cancer/oliai-cure-leukemia #LeukemiaTreatment #CancerResearch #UCLAHealth #iNKTCellTherapy #AML
tags: LeukemiaTreatment,CancerResearch,UCLAHealth,iNKTCellTherapy,AML
caption: false

videoTitle: UCLA Health Pediatric Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) Program
videoDescription: The UCLA Health Pediatric IBD Program is one of the few programs in the country offering leading-edge, multispecialty, advanced treatment for children with IBD. We have the skills and expertise to support children as their needs evolve from infancy through childhood, adolescence and into adulthood. videoTitle: Dr. Dennis Slamon reflects on the development of breast cancer drug Herceptin
videoDescription: Since its introduction in 1998, the revolutionary breast cancer drug Herceptin, developed by a team of scientists led by oncologist Dennis J. Slamon, MD (FEL ‚Äô82), PhD, director of clinical and translational research at the UCLA Health Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center and chief of hematology/oncology at the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, has saved the lives of nearly 3 million women by targeting a specific genetic alteration. Deemed the ‚Äúdrug that changed the breast cancer treatment landscape,‚Äù Herceptin targets cancer at its roots. 25 years later, Dr. Slamon recalls the early days of discovery and development of this drug, as therapies continue to evolve today. Learn more: https://ucla.in/4dHQOJC

videoTitle: Psychosocial Support & Counseling at the Simms Mann Center | UCLA Health
videoDescription: #CancerCare #UCLAHealth A cancer diagnosis impacts patients on many levels ‚Äî emotionally, physically, spiritually, and financially. The Simms/Mann UCLA Center for Integrative Oncology is a resource that helps patients and family members optimize their wellness and address the challenges throughout the continuum of cancer care through a host of programs and services that complement the outstanding research-based clinical care offered here at UCLA. In this video, discover how the Simms/Mann Center honors the emotional, psychological, and spiritual aspects of cancer care by offering additional support at no cost to patients. From providing psychosocial support during chemotherapy to helping patients find meaning through their journey, the Simms/Mann Center is a partner in every step of cancer care. Hear firsthand experiences from people whose lives have been transformed by the Simms/Mann Center's compassionate care. Learn more about how this unique approach helps patients feel more whole, validated, and supported as they navigate living with cancer. Learn more: https://www.uclahealth.org/simms-mann-center #CancerCare #MentalHealth #UCLAHealth #SimmsMannCenter #OncologicalPsychosocial #IntegrativeOncology

videoTitle: How Nutrition Support at the Simms Mann Center Enhances Cancer Care | UCLA Health
videoDescription: #CancerNutrition #UCLAHealth #IntegrativeOncology The Simms/Mann UCLA Center for Integrative Oncology enhances cancer care with its top-quality nutrition services. In this video, see how registered dietitians play an essential role in helping patients navigate their nutritional needs during treatment. Our registered dietitians understand the unique needs of people with cancer and can help patients prepare for treatment, manage side effects, and have more energy during recovery. We offer individualized support to address specific symptoms, issues, and treatment side effects that affect eating, and develop personalized meal plans that empower patients to take control of their health during the challenges of cancer treatment. Find out why the Simms/Mann Center‚Äôs free, expert nutrition services are a vital part of comprehensive cancer care and how they help patients feel more confident and supported. Learn more: https://www.uclahealth.org/simms-mann-center #SimmsMannCenter #CancerNutrition #UCLAHealth #IntegrativeOncology #NutritionInCancerCare #WholePersonCare #CancerSupport

Hear the answer from those who‚Äôve experienced it firsthand. Explore the unique approach of the Simms/Mann Center, which integrates whole-person care and offers services at no cost. The Simms/Mann Center's innovative approach to cancer care provides essential psychosocial support at no cost, removing financial barriers and ensuring comprehensive care. videoDescription: #MentalHealth #CancerCare #UCLAHealth #SimmsMann #SimmsMannCenter The Simms/Mann UCLA Center for Integrative Oncology is revolutionizing cancer care by addressing both the physical aspects of the disease and the mental and emotional well-being of patients. videoTitle: Neurogenetics: Genetics in Neuropsychiatric Illness and Genetic-Based Treatments l Dr. Geschwind
videoDescription: Listen to this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast at: https://www.buzzsprout.com/2265350/share Visit https://www.brainsportpodcast.com to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. Follow us on social media: Instagram: @adel.neuro and @_brainsport X: @Ahdelneuro In this episode, we are honored to have Dr. Daniel Geschwind, a renowned expert in neurogenetics, join us for a compelling conversation. Dr. Geschwind holds the prestigious titles of Gordon and Virginia MacDonald Distinguished Professor of Human Genetics, Neurology and Psychiatry at UCLA. He is also the Senior Associate Dean and Associate Vice Chancellor of Precision Health. In this episode, he shares his profound insights into the intersection of neurogenetics with neuropsychiatric diseases and traumatic brain injuries. Together, we delve into the exciting world of neurogenetics, exploring how this rapidly evolving field is transforming the diagnosis and treatment of various conditions. Dr. Geschwind discusses current advancements, innovative applications and future directions in neurogenetics, providing a comprehensive understanding of its impact on precision health. videoTitle: Homeless Healthcare Collaborative street medicine team brings care to our community
videoDescription: Since 2022, UCLA Health's Homeless Healthcare Collaborative program has cared for thousands of unhoused people in our Los Angeles community. Our street medicine care model is unlike any other in L.A. County, with mobile clinics travel directly to people experiencing homelessness on the streets and in shelters, encampments, interim housing sites, libraries and soup kitchens. We deliver care seven days a week. Hear from patients Bobby Joe and Kelly about the mobility of services. Our unique care model enables us to address the needs of unhoused individuals, regardless of their insurance coverage, immigration status or other factors. Learn more, and how your support helps: https://www.uclahealth.org/programs/hhc

videoTitle: Navigating the waves: beating rectal cancer with a teammate's support
videoDescription: In 2016, Hilary discovered her passion as an outrigger paddler, spending time on the ocean. She met Lisa in an outrigger canoe team in Ventura Harbor. In November 2021, Hilary Witbrodt noticed something unusual - she wasn't sure if it was stress or hemorrhoids. When she was diagnosed with rectal cancer, she felt scared. Hilary realized Lisa was an oncology nurse at UCLA Health, and had her by her side on her first day of chemotherapy. Lisa provided the reassurance, comfort, and familiarity that helped Hilary get through this period. A little over a year later, Hilary and Lisa have a closer-than-ever friendship, and are sharing what they both initially bonded over: paddling. Read the full story: https://ucla.in/3IWjHVw
caption: true

videoTitle: Extreme Sports, Overcoming Fear and Achieving Flow State l Owen Fox
videoDescription: Listen to this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast at: https://www.buzzsprout.com/2265350/share Visit https://www.brainsportpodcast.com to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. Follow us on social media: Instagram: @adel.neuro and @_brainsport X: @Ahdelneuro Join Dr. Daniel Rafie, Sports Neurologist and host of the UCLA BrainSPORT podcast, in an exhilarating conversation with professional downhill skateboarder, Owen Fox. In this episode, they delve into the world of extreme sports, exploring the psychology behind overcoming fear and achieving the elusive flow state. Owen shares his firsthand experiences in downhill skateboarding, shedding light on the adrenaline-fueled thrills and the potential dangers inherent in his sport. Tune in as they discuss the mental and physical challenges of extreme sports and how athletes like Owen navigate the fine line between passion and risk. videoTitle: Colorectal cancer diagnoses are increasing: what can we do?
videoDescription: Since 1995, there has been a 45% increase in colorectal cancer diagnoses in people under the age of 50. The recommended age for your first colorectal cancer screening has been lowered from age 50 to 45. Although diagnoses are increasing, it‚Äôs estimated that more than half of colorectal cancer deaths could be prevented by early detection through screening. Start screening early and continue to have it done regularly. Read more about risk factors, prevention, and steps you can take to help reduce risk: https://ucla.in/3IF1ziR
tags: Colorectal Cancer,Colon Cancer,Colorectal Cancer Screening
caption: false

videoTitle: Colorectal Cancer Screening Saves Lives by Catching Cancer Early
videoDescription: Colorectal Cancer is now the leading cause of cancer death for men under 50, and the second leading cause of cancer death for women under 50. Dr. Folasade May, UCLA Health cancer prevention researcher and gastroenterologist, and a member of the UCLA Health Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center, shares that since 1995, there has been a 45% increase in colorectal cancer diagnoses in people under the age of 50. More than half of colorectal cancer deaths could be prevented by early detection through screening. We urge everyone to start getting regular screenings at 45. The previous recommended screening age was 50. Read more about risk factors, prevention, and steps you can take to help reduce risk: https://ucla.in/3IF1ziR
tags: Colorectal Cancer,Colorectal Cancer Screening,Colorectal Cancer Awareness,UCLA Health Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center,Digestive Diseases
caption: false

videoTitle: How to support heart health through fitness
videoDescription: Think you need to take 10,000 steps every day to feel health benefits? Studies show that heart health benefits start at 2,500 steps/day, but the more steps you can take, the better. With busy schedules, it can be difficult to carve out time for working out. Many adults practice the ‚ÄúWeekend Warrior‚Äô approach, which concentrates moderate-to-vigorous fitness on a select 1-2 days each week. Being a weekend warrior is still associated with lower risks of: üíô Heart attack üíõ Heart failure üíô Stroke So remember: each week, aim for at least 150 minutes of exercise for health benefits. Whenever you can fit in the time, stay active!
tags: Heart Health,Fitness,Cardiology Tips,Sports Cardiologist,Heart Health Month,Heart Disease Awareness
caption: false

videoTitle: Orthopaedic Surgeon Helps Jacqueline Celebrate her 50th Anniversary of the Boston Marathon
videoDescription: Jacqueline Hansen grew up loving the solitude of running. As an accomplished runner, she won the Boston Marathon in 1973. In 2023, 50 years later, she was invited back to receive a special honor of shooting the starting gun. Unfortunately, on the eve of her trip, her shoulder gave out, due to severe arthritis. Orthopaedic surgeon Dr. Andy Jensen explains how Jacqueline needed a shoulder replacement, but she didn't want to miss the race. Thanks to care from the UCLA Health surgeon, she was able to travel to Boston for her 50th anniversary of winning the Boston Marathon. Raising her arm up with assistance, she fired the starting pistol at the beginning of the race. Upon returning, Jacqueline focused on her operation and physical therapy, and is on a successful road to full recovery.
tags: UCLA,UCLA Health,Shoulder Replacement,Shoulder Surgery,Boston Marathon,Running,Fitness,Sports,Jensen,Andy,Jacqueline Hansen,Orthopaedics,Orthopedic,Orthopaedic Surgeon,Orthopedic Surgeon,Reconstructive Surgery,Dr. Andy Jensen

videoTitle: Strengthening the core: Active Spinal Extension:
videoDescription: Active Spinal Extension: Targets abdominal muscles, promoting stronger lower back muscles. Daily activities such as lifting heavy objects, bending, twisting ‚Äî or even sitting at a desk for prolonged periods ‚Äî require a stable core. Strengthening this central support improves functional fitness, making everyday movements easier and more efficient. A strong core conveys benefits to the entire body: Equally important, a strong core can alleviate and prevent back pain. Strong core muscles provide essential support to the spine, reducing strain on the lower back and promoting a healthier posture. Learn more about exercises to strengthen the core: https://ucla.in/3u4q5WR

videoTitle: Strengthening the core: Shoulder plank
videoDescription: Shoulder plank: A classic exercise that engages multiple core muscles simultaneously, including the rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis and obliques. Daily activities such as lifting heavy objects, bending, twisting ‚Äî or even sitting at a desk for prolonged periods ‚Äî require a stable core. Strengthening this central support improves functional fitness, making everyday movements easier and more efficient. A strong core conveys benefits to the entire body: Equally important, a strong core can alleviate and prevent back pain. Strong core muscles provide essential support to the spine, reducing strain on the lower back and promoting a healthier posture. Learn more about exercises to strengthen the core: https://ucla.in/3u4q5WR

Ryan‚Äôs stellar career and his road to the NFL. Hall of Fame was suddenly cut short by an on-field spinal cord injury. Ryan was given less than a 20% chance of walking again, but despite these odds, he was able to make a miraculous recovery and is now walking and leading a fulfilled life. The pair discuss the context of his injury and the physical and psychological consequences that resulted from it. videoTitle: Gout: What you need to know
videoDescription: Gout is a type of inflammatory arthritis, which usually starts with bouts of severe swelling, redness and pain at the big toe, but can affect any joints ‚Äî or multiple joints ‚Äî at the same time. People with gout experience flare-ups, known as gout attacks, which can be extremely painful and disruptive. But there‚Äôs more to gout than just the attacks. In this video, you‚Äôll learn about gout ‚Äî how it starts, what causes and flare-up, and how to treat gout attacks and cure the disease, preventing future attacks. To learn about about gout, go to uclahealth.org/medical-services/rheumatology/gout

videoDescription: Visit¬†https://www.brainsportpodcast.com¬†to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. Join host Adel in this UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast episode featuring Dr. Chris Palmer, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and the author of the best-selling book, Brain Energy. In the part A of this two-part series, they dissect the Brain Energy Theory for Mental Illness. The pair assesses the current state of mental illness diagnosis and management, emphasizing certain shortcomings. The heart of the discussion is the Brain Energy Theory. The duo explore how mitochondrial dysfunction plays a key role in mental illness and the evidence to substantiate this theory. videoTitle: AUD: What Are My Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) Treatment Options and How Do I Find Them? (English)
videoDescription: Join Stephanie Aguirre, MSW, a licensed clinical social worker from the liver transplant team at UCLA Health, as she discusses the available treatment options for alcohol use disorder (AUD) and how to find them. AUD treatment is available in both inpatient and outpatient settings. Ms. Aguirre will walk you through each of these options and reasons why you may want to choose one form of treatment over another. To find treatment, you may start by contacting your insurance provider who can provide a list of in-network behavioral health providers. You can also ask for a referral from your primary care provider (PCP). A third option is to search online in directories like psychologytoday.com and through the NIAAA Navigator. In the last part of this video, Ms. Aguirre will walk you through a real life demonstration of using these two websites. It is our hope this demonstration will help in facilitating your search for treatment. If you‚Äôre worried about your drinking and would like more information, please visit: https://www.uclahealth.org Learn more about liver transplant services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/transplants/liver-transplant
caption: false

videoTitle: What is Alcohol Use Disorder (English subtitles)
videoDescription: Did you know that alcohol use disorder (AUD) affects a staggering 14.5 million Americans over the age of 12? Despite its prevalence, less than 10% of adults receive any form of treatment. AUD is a condition that leads to negative health consequences and symptoms. In this video, watch as Sammy Saab, MD MPH, highlights the relationship between AUD and liver disease, stressing the critical need to address the underlying AUD along with liver disease. Contrary to a common misconception, overcoming AUD is not solely reliant on willpower. Support from family, friends, the medical team, and the community is crucial for patients in their recovery. Treatment for AUD is a journey that takes time and resilience. UCLA Health is here to support individuals through their AUD treatment and provide compassionate, high-quality medical services to address it. If you‚Äôre worried about your drinking and would like more information, please visit: https://www.uclahealth.org Learn more about liver transplant services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/transplants/liver-transplant
caption: false

videoTitle: AUD: Alcohol Use Disorder and Transplants (English subtitles)
videoDescription: UCLA Health patients Raul Sansores and Trend Ford share their experiences on recovery from alcohol use during the pre- and post-liver transplantation process. They emphasize that a liver transplant is not a magical fix, but a starting point for a lifelong commitment to recovery. Watch the video to see their journey of hope as they found solace in the compassionate care provided by the medical team at UCLA Health. Their caregivers, including spouses and family members, also share their own perspectives on the journey, highlighting the importance of self-care and seeking support while caring for their loved ones. They provide valuable advice and encouragement for others who may be facing similar challenges. Join Raul, Trent, and their loved ones as they share stories of resilience, self-discovery, and the transformative power of embracing a new lease on life. Learn more about the transplant services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/transplants/liver-transplant

videoTitle: Moyamoya | Anthony C. Wang, MD, UCLA Moyamoya Program |UCLA Health
videoDescription: Jeremiah Johnson, MD, FAANS, and Anthony Wang, MD explain moyamoya disease, which involves the narrowing of blood vessels in the brain. Moyomoya is rare and affects people of all ages, but it accounts for 10-20% of all strokes that occur in children. When a person has moyamoya, backup blood vessels form in the brain to make up for the lack of blood and oxygen caused by narrowing. Compared to healthy blood vessels, those backup vessels are smaller and weaker. Over time, moyamoya can cause bleeding in the brain or a stroke. The most common symptoms of moyamoya disease include brain bleeding (hemorrhage), headaches, personality changes, cognitive dysfunction, problems with senses (sight, touch, hearing, taste, smell) and seizures. There is no cure for moyamoya at this time, but treatments can help manage symptoms and prevent serious complications like seizure and stroke. Bypass surgery using donor arteries can help divert blood flow. In this webinar, Dr. Wang shows a bypass surgery and explains how the procedure is performed. Learn more about the neurosurgery services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/neurosurgery

videoTitle: What to Expect from Additional Breast Imaging | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Meet Cheryce Poon Fischer, MD, and Hannah Milch, MD, as they explain what it means if you're called back for additional imaging after a mammogram. Callbacks after a mammogram are relatively common and often result in normal findings. During your callback visit, you can expect more imaging tests like mammograms and ultrasounds. If necessary, your doctor might recommend a biopsy, but remember, a callback alone is not a breast cancer diagnosis. It's essential to follow through with recommended tests and appointments for early detection and peace of mind. Make sure to provide any past breast imaging, arrive early, and expect your visit to take about 45 to 60 minutes. Your care team will explain your results after the exam, and they are here to support and answer any questions you have. Learn more about the breast imaging and screening process at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/radiology/breast-imaging/diagnostic-exams/breast-imaging-screening-mammogram
caption: false

videoTitle: What to Expect from a Screening Mammogram | UCLA Health
videoDescription: In this video, Cheryce Poon Fischer, MD and Dr. Hannah Milch, MD, provide an overview of the UCLA Breast Imaging Screening Program and what to expect. Most women should have annual mammograms beginning at age 40, with earlier screenings for those who have a higher risk of breast cancer. On the day of your mammogram, arrive 15 minutes early to fill out any required paperwork on an iPad. Once your care team is ready for you, they will guide you through the mammogram process, during which a state-of-the-art 3D mammogram captures detailed breast images. After your mammogram is complete, imaging results will be available in your MyChart patient portal called myUCLAHealth. You will also receive your results in the mail. Remember to schedule your yearly mammogram. Learn more: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/radiology/breast-imaging/diagnostic-exams/breast-imaging-screening-mammogram
caption: false

videoTitle: Endocrine Fellowship Program | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Learn about the UCLA Division of Endocrinology and Endocrine Fellowship Program from division leadership, faculty and fellows. With an annual enrollment of 5 to 6 clinical fellows, this program is a cornerstone in the field. Leveraging a flexible curriculum, fellows can tailor their training experience, engage with top experts, gain exposure to unique cases, and develop into skilled clinical endocrinologists. Beyond the learning environment, fellows become part of a close-knit community, participating in diverse activities that enrich their experience. Through both clinical practice and research, UCLA Health gives fellows the tools and experience they need to graduate with confidence and competence. Learn more: https://www.uclahealth.org/departments/medicine/endocrinology/fellowship-program

videoTitle: Getting Ready for Endocrine Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Dr. Michael Yeh, an endocrine surgeon at UCLA Health, explains how to prepare for endocrine surgery. Before surgery, it's natural to have questions. Jot them down to ensure nothing's missed during your consultation. Once you're set on surgery, a UCLA Health scheduler will help you choose a date and location among our three centers. Leading up to your surgery, eat a balanced diet with lean protein and exercise 20 minutes each day to prep your body. Around three weeks before your surgery date, we'll help you finalize pre-operative tasks and insurance arrangements to minimize financial stress. Fasting is important. Avoid solid food for eight hours before surgery and clear liquids for two hours before. Plan to arrive about two hours ahead of the surgery time. If you live an hour away or more, plan to be in the West L.A. area three hours prior. The operating room nursing staff will guide you through the pre-op process. If you have any questions or concerns, talk to your doctor. Learn more about endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Thyroid Stimulating Hormone | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), produced by the pituitary gland, is essential for healthy thyroid function, says UCLA Health endocrinologist Angela Leung. This butterfly-shaped gland in your neck regulates metabolism and relies on iodine from your diet to create thyroid hormones. Similar to how a gas pedal works, TSH controls thyroid hormone production. Elevated TSH signifies underproduction (hypothyroidism), while low TSH indicates overproduction (hyperthyroidism). Monitoring TSH levels helps your doctor gauge your thyroid health and metabolism regulation. Learn more about conditions affecting the thyroid: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery/conditions-treated
caption: false

videoTitle: Symptoms of Thyroid Cancer | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: What are thyroid cancer symptoms? In this video, UCLA Health endocrinologist Angela Leung explains. One of the most common symptoms of thyroid cancer is a thyroid nodule. These bumps on the thyroid are common ‚Äî by the time you reach age 50, it's more likely that you will have a thyroid nodule than not. Only around 1 in 10 to 20 thyroid nodules are cancerous. Many people who are diagnosed with thyroid cancer don‚Äôt experience any symptoms, and most thyroid nodules have minimal impact on thyroid function. Sometimes large nodules can cause trouble swallowing or a hoarse voice, but most thyroid cancers are detected when smaller. It‚Äôs important to note that thyroid nodules (cancerous or benign) usually don't cause pain; consult your doctor if you experience discomfort. If you have any remaining questions, talk to your doctor for more personalized guidance and advice. Learn more about thyroid cancer and other conditions affecting the thyroid: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery/conditions-treated
caption: false

videoTitle: Parathyroid Hormone | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Watch as Dr. Yaroslav Gofnung, a UCLA Health endocrinologist, explains the parathyroid hormone. Parathyroid glands, nestled near your thyroid, produce parathyroid hormone (PTH). This hormone is a calcium regulator, so it plays a pivotal role in maintaining balanced blood calcium levels. PTH helps raise blood calcium levels by prompting bones to release calcium, enhancing calcium absorption from food, and lowering calcium loss through urine. When there‚Äôs a parathyroid hormone imbalance, like hyperparathyroidism, it can cause health issues. If you're concerned about your parathyroid hormone levels or related symptoms, talk to your doctor for more personalized guidance. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: Thyroglobulin and Thyroglobulin Antibodies | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Watch as UCLA Health endocrinologist Yaroslav Gofnung explains thyroglobulin and thyroglobulin antibodies. The thyroglobulin blood test helps monitor thyroid cancer recurrence. When thyroglobulin rises after complete thyroid removal, it could indicate cancer growth. In cases where patients have remaining thyroid tissue, this test may not provide the same insight. Thyroglobulin antibody test detects antibodies that mistakenly attack thyroid protein. This points to thyroid issues like Hashimoto's or Graves' disease. At UCLA Health, we offer specialized thyroid globulin testing, even if you have antibodies. If you have questions about these tests, turn to your endocrinologist for personalized guidance and advice. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: Life After Thyroid Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: What‚Äôs life like after thyroid surgery? In this video from UCLA Health, endocrinologist Yaroslav Gofnung explains. After thyroid surgery, having questions and feeling a wide range of emotions are common. Remember that you're not alone in this journey. The emotional impact of having thyroid surgery real. It's normal to feel a rollercoaster of emotions. Seek support and share your feelings. You might need lifelong thyroid hormone replacement, but once the right dosage is found, you‚Äôll start to feel much better. There are many positives that await you post-surgery ‚Äì your energy levels should rise, and many people experience improved quality of life. With regular follow-ups and your care team by your side, you can thrive. Find more information about endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Side Effects of Thyroid Hormones | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: What are the possible side effects from thyroid hormone medications? UCLA Health endocrinologist Yaroslav Gofnung explains. Thyroid hormone meds can come with side effects, but not everyone experiences them. It often depends on a person‚Äôs dosage. Common side effects include heart-related sensations, shaking, sweating, heat sensitivity, nervousness, changes in bowel movements, appetite changes, and temporary hair loss. Frequent follow-ups and dose changes can help alleviate these unwanted side effects. Work with your doctor to find the right dosage and follow-up with your doctor if you experience anything concerning. They can tailor your medication and options to better suit your needs and improve your quality of life. For more personalized guidance, talk to your endocrinologist, who is here to help. Find more information about endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Is Thyroid Cancer Fatal | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Watch as UCLA Health endocrinologist Angela Leung answers a tough but frequently asked question: Is thyroid cancer fatal? Thyroid cancer, which affects the butterfly-shaped gland in your neck, is treatable. Surgery, followed by targeted therapies often promotes successful outcomes. A person‚Äôs prognosis varies based on cancer type, stage, and general health. But early detection significantly improves survival rates ‚Äî 98 out of 100 people survive Stage 1 for five years. Younger patients often fare even better. Understanding and keeping a lookout for symptoms, like neck lumps or swallowing difficulties, is key for early diagnosis. If you have any questions or concerns, talk to your doctor for more personalized advice. Learn more about thyroid cancer and other conditions affecting the thyroid: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery/conditions-treated
caption: false

videoTitle: Weight Gain After Thyroid Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Are you worried about gaining weight after thyroid surgery? In this video, Dr. Angela Leung, from the UCLA Health Endocrine Center, provides her insights. Understanding the thyroid's role in metabolism is key. The butterfly-shaped gland creates thyroid hormones and uses them to regulate your metabolism. Surgery might mean you need thyroid hormone replacement, depending on the extent. But even with partial removal, the remaining thyroid might be able to produce enough hormones ‚Äî every person is different. Weight gain is possible post-surgery if thyroid medication dosage is insufficient. Low thyroid hormone levels can slow your metabolism, affecting energy and weight. Regular thyroid blood tests help monitor hormone levels. Remember, factors like appetite shifts and activity changes can also contribute to weight. Talk to your care team for more personalized guidance in this area. Explore endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Common Wound Complaints After Endocrine Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Dr. Michael Yeh, an endocrine surgeon at UCLA Health, addresses common post-op wound complaints. The most common concern after thyroid or parathyroid surgery is a healing ridge ‚Äî a temporary, firm bump or swelling beneath the incision. This is your body's natural response, and it gradually fades within 6 to 8 weeks. Itching or a rash around the wound, sometimes extending to the shoulders and chest, affects some people due to an allergic reaction to disinfectant. Gently cleanse with warm water and soap. Redness and itching around the bandage can stem from an adhesive allergy. Hydrocortisone cream can help manage this issue, but serious reactions like severe swelling or skin blistering warrant a call to your doctor. Learn more about endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Taking Calcium After Parathyroid Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: What kind of calcium management would you need after parathyroid surgery? In this video, UCLA Health's endocrine surgeon Kyle Zanocco explains. After parathyroidectomy, your blood calcium levels might fluctuate due to your parathyroid‚Äôs role in calcium regulation. You can expect a prescribed calcium supplement, often using Tums (calcium carbonate tablets). Dosage and frequency are tailored to your needs. In some cases, vitamin D supplements, like calcitriol, are suggested to enhance calcium absorption by doubling its effectiveness. Post-surgery recovery can take anywhere from 2 to 6 weeks, and you‚Äôll gradually reduce your calcium supplement intake until it's no longer necessary. Remember that every person is different. For more personalized advice, talk to your endocrine surgeon or endocrinologist. Learn more about endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Thyroid Hormone Medication After Thyroid Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Curious about thyroid surgery and the need for medication afterward? Join Dr. Kyle Zanocco, an endocrine surgeon from UCLA Health, as he breaks down the answer to this common question. Your thyroid gland impacts crucial functions like metabolism, energy levels and body temperature. After surgery, you might have to replace the hormones it can no longer produce on its own. If your entire thyroid was removed, medication is a must. But if only part of the thyroid was taken out, the need for medication depends on the reason behind the surgery. In most cases, you might be prescribed levothyroxine, a synthetic thyroid hormone. This medication is like what your thyroid used to make naturally. Remember that every patient is unique. Based on your situation, your doctor will tailor the medication dose and monitor your thyroid hormone levels regularly. Learn more about endocrine surgery at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Immune-tolerance is the pinnacle of transplantation
videoDescription: Transplantation is no different from other lifelong illnesses that requires newer, safer and more effective treatment options. Performing human-organ transplants without the necessity for lifelong dependence on immunosuppressive drugs has been an enduring goal for transplantation medicine. UCLA Health made a groundbreaking delayed-immune-tolerance protocol that will help kidney transplant recipients get off all their immunosuppressive medications. Watch the video to discover how UCLA Health is revolutionizing transplant medicine. Learn more about our delayed- Immune-tolerance Program: https://ucla.in/3nuHguE
caption: false

videoDescription: Visit¬†https://www.brainsportpodcast.com¬†to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. He is a regular contributor for the New York Times and his work has been featured in the Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post among other publications. He recently published his book "The Practice of Groundedness", in which he creates a structured approach to implementing these principles. The pair begin by speaking about the reason Brad wrote this book. They then go on to discuss the concept of heroic individualism and why it falls short and is not a sustainable mindset for achieving long term success. Their conversation then covers The Practice of Groundedness from a high level view and how this is an improved approach to performance. They discuss initial concepts on the practice such as, focusing on the process (instead of the goal), acceptance, tempering expectations, and our sense of self and identity. videoTitle: Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) in Football l Chris Nowinski, PhD and Kevin Bickart, MD PhD
videoDescription: Visit¬†https://www.brainsportpodcast.com¬†to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. On this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) with founder and CEO of the Concussion Legacy Foundation and former WWE professional wrestler, Dr. Chris Nowinski. Also joining the pair is UCLA Assistant Professor of Neurobehavioral and Sports Neurology, Dr. Kevin Bickart. The trio begin with a discussion on Miami Dolphins quarterback, Tua Tagoivaloa's multiple concussions experienced last season and their implications. They then go on to discuss CTE, the dementia diagnosed in a number of American football players after their deaths. Specific topics discussed include: what kinds of head injuries are believed to contribute to CTE, whether there is a causal relationship between repetitive head injuries and CTE, the particularly violent and aggressive behaviors demonstrated by certain football players who were diagnosed with CTE, and high-level ways to prevent CTE, including banning youth tackle football. Listen to this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast: https://www.buzzsprout.com/2265350/share Follow us on social media! Instagram: @adel.neuro X: @Ahdelneuro 0:00 Do Repeated Head Impacts Cause Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE)? 1:24 Tua Tagovailoa‚Äôs Concussions 8:07 Tua‚Äôs Prognosis 9:18 Should Tua Retire? 13:23 Sub concussions, non-concussive head injuries, and CTE 18:53 Persistent Post-Concussion Symptoms vs CTE 20:36 Prevalence of CTE 26:13 Violent Behavior in CTE 31:49 The Connection between CTE pathology and symptoms 36:06 The Bradford Hill Criteria applied to CTE 41:46 The Causal Relationship between repetitive head injuries and CTE 52:20 Changing football rules and policy 59:16 Future directions to prevent and treat CTE 1:05:01 Closing Remarks

videoTitle: Surgical Advances: Endoscopic Transnasal Surgery for Pituitary and Anterior Skull Base Tumors
videoDescription: Marvin Bergsneider, MD and Jeremiah Johnson, MD, discuss recent advances in a minimally invasive surgery for brain tumors called endoscopic transnasal surgery. During this procedure, surgeons insert an endoscope (camera) through the nose and expose and remove tumors from base of the brain. Guided by the endoscope camera, specially designed microsurgical instruments are used to dissect and remove the tumor. There is no facial incision, no visible scar and often fewer side effects for patients. If left untreated, pituitary and anterior skull base tumors can cause many health problems, including Cushing‚Äôs disease. In ideal cases, surgery can remove the tumor and resolve symptoms. Endoscopic transnasal surgery is a groundbreaking treatment because it allows doctors to see and remove tumors in otherwise difficult to reach areas ‚Äî without a skin incision, with increased precision and better results. Watch the webinar to learn more about how surgeons at UCLA Health use endoscopic transnasal surgery to remove pituitary and skull base tumors. Learn more about treatment for pituitary and skull base tumors: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/neurosurgery/pituitary-skull-base-tumor/treatment-options
tags: neurosurgery,medical,surgery,innovation,ucla,ucla health

videoTitle: Neurosurgery Research Update: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Isaac Yang, MD, Quinton Gopen, MD and Jeremiah Johnson, MD, discuss a disorder termed superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD), its diagnosis, treatments and outcomes of patients undergoing surgery at UCLA. More common among older adults, SSCD happens when a small hole develops in the bony layer covering one of the three balance organ canals inside the ear. The hole causes symptoms like hearing loss, vertigo, fatigue, headaches, disequilibrium and more. Watch as Dr. Gopen and Dr. Yang explain evidence-based research behind SSCD and how it impacts treatment. SSCD is an active area of clinical research at UCLA Health ‚Äî Dr. Gopen and Dr. Yang have completed 500 surgeries (at the time of recording) with guidance from revolutionary neuronavigation technology. Surgery is often successful ‚Äî most patients in the clinical series saw at least one symptom improve following surgical treatment. Watch the full webinar to learn more about the SSCD clinical research and neuronavigation assisted surgery at UCLA Health. Explore more about SSCD at: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/neurosurgery/brain-tumor/conditions/meningioma-and-skullbase-tumor-program/semicircular-canal-dehiscence https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JzxYKndgp5w https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I4dcLdq_WIc

videoTitle: 22: The Power of the Downstate, Optimizing Sleep and Recovery l Sara Mednick, PhD
videoDescription: Visit¬†https://www.brainsportpodcast.com¬†to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. On this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses Sleep and the Downstate with UC Irvine cognitive and sleep¬†neuroscientist and author of The Power of the Downstate, Dr. Sara Mednick. The pair start by discussing the downstate and why it is so important for our day-to-day performance and optimizing recovery. Their discussion covers methods to enhance recovery including timing of exercise and meals. They then discuss sleep and how it relates to our performance, the risk of dementia, and much more. They also discuss methods of promoting sleep and the influence of certain substances on sleep, including stimulants. videoTitle: Risks and Complications of Thyroid Surgery | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, James Wu, MD, an endocrine surgeon at the UCLA Endocrine Center, talks about the risks involved in thyroid surgery. While thyroid surgery is generally safe, complications can occur. The UCLA Endocrine Center takes these risks seriously and works to minimize them as much as possible. Learn more about services at the UCLA Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Can Your Thyroid Affect Your Lymph Nodes? | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, James Wu, MD, an endocrine surgeon at the UCLA Endocrine Center, explains how thyroid diseases affect lymph nodes. Lymph nodes are bean-shaped structures that filter the fluid in our bodies and catch harmful things like bacteria, viruses, and cancer cells. It's common for people to have swollen lymph nodes from colds, flus, and vaccines, but sometimes swollen lymph nodes are a sign of something more serious, like thyroid cancer. Doctors should look at the lymph nodes in patients with possible thyroid cancer or those who have already been diagnosed with it. Learn more about services at the UCLA Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: What Does It Mean if Your Calcium Is High? | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Learn what it means if you have high levels of calcium in your blood, as explained by Stephanie Smooke Praw, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: What Do the Parathyroid Glands Do? | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Stephanie Smooke Praw, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, discusses the parathyroid glands. These small glands are located near the thyroid gland and produce a hormone called parathyroid hormone (PTH). This hormone helps control the levels of calcium, phosphorus, and vitamin D in the blood. Maintaining the right level of calcium in your blood is essential for your health, as it helps keep your bones strong and your body functioning properly. If the calcium levels in your blood get too low, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which tells your body to start absorbing more calcium from your food and releasing it from your bones. But if your calcium levels get too high, the parathyroid gland releases less PTH, which helps prevent your body from absorbing too much calcium from your food or releasing too much from your bones. It's important to maintain the right balance of calcium levels in your body, and if you're experiencing any symptoms related to the parathyroid glands, talk to your doctor. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: Signs of Hypothyroidism | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Stephanie Smooke Praw, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, explains the signs of hypothyroidism. This is a condition caused by not having enough thyroid hormone. The thyroid gland, a small butterfly-shaped gland in the neck, produces hormones that help control certain functions in the body. Sometimes the thyroid doesn‚Äôt produce enough hormones. This causes symptoms like feeling more tired or sluggish than usual, sensitivity to cold, constipation or difficulty having a bowel movement, dry skin, hair loss, and weight gain even with a healthy diet and regular exercise. If you think you might have hypothyroidism, schedule an appointment with your doctor. Learn more about services at the UCLA Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Signs of Hyperthyroidism | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Stephanie Smooke Praw, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, explains hyperthyroidism. This medical condition happens when the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone. The thyroid is a small gland in the neck that releases hormones to regulate certain body functions. When it releases too much thyroid hormone, a person can experience heart palpitations, hand tremors, excessive sweating, frequent loose stools, anxiety and weight loss. If these symptoms persist, it's important to see a doctor or an endocrinologist for evaluation. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: What Are Signs of Adrenal Problems? | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Masha Livhits, MD, an endocrine surgeon at the UCLA Endocrine Center, discusses the signs and symptoms of adrenal problems. Located above the kidneys, the adrenal glands produce hormones that regulate different body functions. If there‚Äôs a mass or nodule in the adrenal gland, it could create too many hormones and cause problems. High blood pressure is the most common sign of an adrenal problem. Other symptoms include weight gain, muscle weakness, mood swings, skin changes, irregular periods in women and increased thirst and urination. Learn more about services at the UCLA Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Can You Live a Normal Life With One Adrenal Gland? | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Masha Livhits, MD, an endocrine surgeon at the UCLA Endocrine Center, explains how if one adrenal gland is removed, most patients can live a normal life. The adrenal glands produce hormones to control blood pressure, manage stress, and use energy from food. Sometimes, adrenal nodules can grow and produce too much hormone, causing health problems. In these cases, surgery is recommended to remove the adrenal gland. Learn more about services at the UCLA Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: What Is Graves‚Äô Disease? | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Pouyan Famini, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, discusses Graves‚Äô disease, a common autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland. What's unique about this disease is that it causes a specific antibody to stick to the thyroid gland, telling it to produce more thyroid hormone. This leads to hyperthyroidism, which can cause symptoms like anxiety, shaking, sensitivity to heat, weight loss and frequent bowel movements. If you're experiencing any of these symptoms, there is hope. UCLA Health has several treatment options for Graves‚Äô disease, including anti-thyroid drugs, radioactive iodine or surgery. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: Treatment Options for Graves‚Äô Disease | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Pouyan Famini, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, discusses treatment options for Graves' disease in this video. Anti-thyroid drugs, radioactive iodine and surgery are three options for treating this autoimmune disorder. Anti-thyroid drugs are often the first treatment, as they help to lower the amount of thyroid hormone the thyroid gland produces. Sometimes remission occurs while taking these medications ‚Äî if that happens, the patient can discontinue use. Keep in mind that anti-thyroid medications can cause side effects, and in rare cases, they can cause liver and bone marrow problems. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: The Best Way to Take Thyroid Hormone | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Pouyan Famini, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, provides some basic directions for taking thyroid hormones. Dr. Pouyan recommends taking thyroid medication on an empty stomach, around 30 to 60 minutes before a meal, and at least three or more hours after the last meal. This is because the body absorbs the medication better when there's no food in the stomach. If patients take the medication after eating, the body might not absorb as much of the thyroid medication. Learn more about the endocrinology services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/endocrinology
caption: false

videoTitle: Receiving Radioactive Iodine for Thyroid Cancer | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: In this video, Pouyan Famini, MD, an endocrinologist at the UCLA Endocrine Center, explains how radioactive iodine treatment for thyroid cancer works. Radioactive iodine therapy is a treatment that uses iodine to target and kill thyroid cells. The goal of this treatment is to destroy any remaining cancer cells in the body. This treats thyroid cancer that has spread beyond the thyroid gland, and it also helps prevent the cancer from returning. Learn more about services at the UCLA Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: MMA Embolization: An Emerging Treatment Technique for Chronic Subdural Hematomas | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Geoffrey Colby, MD, PhD, FAANS, and Jeremiah Johnson, MD, FAANS, explain a new treatment used to address chronic subdural hematomas. When someone has a subdural hematoma, blood collects in the space between the surface of the brain and the inner lining of the skull. As the subdural hematoma grows, it puts pressure on the brain, and can cause headaches, confusion, seizures, imbalance and more. By 2030, researchers say that chronic subdural hematomas will be one of the most common surgical conditions requiring treatment by neurosurgeons. One minimally invasive treatment technique is middle meningeal arterial (MMA) embolization. During this procedure, the doctor directs a small catheter through the arteries into the MMA blood vessel in the underlining of the skull called the dura matter. Through the catheter, the surgeon releases particles or glue to reduce MMA blood flow which prevents future bleeding and promotes healing. Watch the webinar to learn more about how UCLA Health surgeons are using this emerging surgical treatment for chronic subdural hematomas. Learn more about the neurosurgery services at UCLA Health: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/neurosurgery
tags: neurosurgery,medical,surgery,innovation,ucla,ucla health
caption: false

videoTitle: Homeless Healthcare Collaborative | UCLA Health
videoDescription: There are almost 80,000 people experiencing homelessness across Los Angeles County. The UCLA Health Homeless Healthcare Collaborative delivers health care and supportive services to unhoused individuals, regardless of insurance coverage, immigration status or other factors. Services are delivered seven day a week and include primary and preventive health care, urgent medical care, chronic disease management, psychiatric primary care, harm reduction services and substance use treatment. Care is delivered out of mobile clinics to people on the streets and in shelters, encampments, interim housing sites, libraries and soup kitchens. The team also provides care coordination services to ensure people get connected to medical and social services, including housing, employment and financial assistance. To learn more, visit the UCLA Health Homeless Healthcare Collaborative website at uclahealth.org/hhc

videoTitle: 21: Creativity: Origins & Associations, Psychedelics, Mental Health, Flow State l Robert Bilder, PhD
videoDescription: Visit¬†https://www.brainsportpodcast.com¬†to subscribe to the BrainSPORT Podcast and access exclusive content unavailable elsewhere. On this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses Creativity with UCLA Tannebaum Creativity Center director Dr. Rober Bilder. The pair start by discussing the definition of creativity, its subjective nature, and the idea that creativity comes from "the edge of chaos." They then discuss the neurobiology of creativity and its association with intelligence and associative thinking. They also discuss whether creativity can be enhanced through disinhibition, neuromodulation, and psychedelics. The episode is finalized by discussing the overlap between mental health disorders and creativity, flow state and tips to enhance creativity. videoTitle: What Causes Thyroid Nodules | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Thyroid nodules are common and are usually detected by ultrasounds, says endocrine surgeon James Wu, MD. One of the main causes of thyroid nodules is increased age. The longer we live, the more likely some of our thyroid cells will develop abnormally into a clump of cells (nodule). Anything that interferes with thyroid function can also cause thyroid nodules. For example, since the thyroid uses iodine to create the thyroid hormone, being iodine deficient can lead to the formation of nodules. Studies have linked other factors to thyroid nodules including smoking, obesity and drinking alcohol. Most thyroid nodules aren‚Äôt an issue, but it‚Äôs important to make sure a thyroid nodule isn‚Äôt interfering with your thyroid function. You should also have the nodule checked for any features suspicious for thyroid cancer. To learn more, explore the UCLA Health Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: What Causes Thyroid Cancer | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid cancer. Significant exposure to radiation can increase a person‚Äôs risk of this type of thyroid cancer, says endocrine surgeon James Wu, MD. Some families have genetic mutations that put them at greater risk for thyroid cancer, which is why family health history is important to discuss with your provider. Most patients haven‚Äôt been exposed to radiation and they don‚Äôt have a family health history of thyroid problems. In these cases, it‚Äôs unknown exactly what causes thyroid cancer. Several studies have looked at smoking, obesity, pesticides and other factors, but the data isn‚Äôt strong enough to prove a direct correlation to thyroid cancer. No matter the cause, long-term outcomes for most thyroid cancer patients at UCLA Health are excellent. If you have questions about your thyroid cancer risk, talk to your health care provider or endocrinologist. Learn more about the UCLA Health Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Thyroid Hormone Preparations | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: When the thyroid gland no longer makes enough thyroid hormone, it‚Äôs called hypothyroidism. This condition is treated by taking a pill form of the thyroid hormone. There are two types of thyroid hormones in the body: T3 and T4. Patients can take synthetic T3 or T4, but the most common is T4. Another way to get more of the thyroid hormone that your body needs is through dried animal thyroid glands, usually from pigs or cows. This is called desiccated thyroid or thyroid extract. For this option, the amount of T3 and T4 hormones in each pill can vary, so it‚Äôs important to discuss this method with your provider. If you have questions or concerns about thyroid hormones, reach out to your health care provider or endocrinologist. For more information, explore the UCLA Health Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Bone Mineral Density Scans | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: A T-score refers to your bone density compared to that of a healthy, 30-something adult. It‚Äôs determined through a special X-ray of your bones called a DEXA scan. This imaging test scans your hips, spine and sometimes wrists. A computer uses the scan to calculate the T-score, which helps doctors understand how dense your bones are, says endocrinologist Yaroslav Gofnung, MD. A normal T-score is between 0 and -1. A T-score between -1 and -2.5 is considered osteopenia. A T-score below -2.5 is considered osteoporosis. The lower the T-score, the higher the risk of breaking a bone. Tracking a T-score over time allows doctors to monitor a person‚Äôs response to treatment if they‚Äôve already been diagnosed with osteoporosis. It can also help doctors determine when (or if) to start or stop treatment. Talk to your health care provider or endocrinologist if you have any questions about a bone mineral density scan. For more information, explore the UCLA Health Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Results of Thyroid Biopsy | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: For most thyroid biopsies, the results are benign (noncancerous), says endocrinologist Yaroslav Gofnung, MD. Sometimes the results come back as indeterminant, which means it‚Äôs unknown if the cells are benign or cancerous. When this happens, the experts at UCLA Health can analyze the genetics of the biopsy. This method is highly accurate and will determine if the cells are suspicious or benign. A third possible result is nondiagnostic, which means the pathologist didn‚Äôt have enough cells to make a conclusion. This often requires a second biopsy. To avoid this result, a cytotechnologist assists in the biopsy to ensure the pathologist has enough cells for a clear diagnosis. This is one way UCLA Health provides the highest standard of care for patients. Explore more information about the UCLA Health Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: TSH and Thyroid Function Tests | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: It‚Äôs normal for doctors to order blood tests to check thyroid health, says endocrinologist Yaroslav Gofnung, MD. A common test checks thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH). Originating from the pituitary gland, TSH tells your body to make the thyroid hormone. If a test shows your TSH value is too high, it usually indicates hypothyroidism. This means the body isn‚Äôt producing enough of the thyroid hormone or you‚Äôre taking too little thyroid hormone medication. On the other hand, a low TSH value often indicates hyperthyroidism ‚Äî when the body produces too much thyroid hormone. A normal TSH value usually means the thyroid is functioning as it should. Talk to your health care provider or endocrinologist when reviewing your thyroid tests. For more information about tests and treatment, explore the UCLA Health Endocrine Center: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Adrenal Nodule or Mass Found on a Scan | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Imaging has gotten better over the years ‚Äî doctors find more adrenal nodules and masses than ever before. These masses, called adrenal incidentalomas, occur in about 7 percent of people by age 70. Most are noncancerous and don‚Äôt cause problems, but some lead to serious disease. Treatment is required if the masses are cancerous or make too many hormones. To find out if the mass is cancerous, doctors usually order a special CT scan. This scan shows the size, density and borders of the tumor. Cancerous tumors are usually bigger than 6cm, are dense and have irregular borders. While rare, some cancerous adrenal tumors are smaller than 6cm, so it‚Äôs important to consider all of the tumor‚Äôs characteristics. Surgery is often recommended to treat adrenal incidentaloma, says endocrine surgeon Avital Harari, MD. If you choose not to remove the mass, it‚Äôs important to have close follow-up with regular imaging and labs to see if the mass changes, which happens in about 20 percent of patients. Learn more about treatment for adrenal incidentalomas: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: How Dangerous is Thyroid Cancer | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Most people have a type of thyroid cancer that‚Äôs slow growing, treatable and curable, says endocrine surgeon Avital Harari, MD. Prognosis depends on the type of thyroid cancer, how far it has spread and your age. Younger age is better ‚Äî with most thyroid cancers, you can‚Äôt present with an advanced stage if you‚Äôre under 55 years old. To determine how dangerous the thyroid cancer is, you need to know whether it has spread to other parts of the body, such as the lymph nodes. A neck ultrasound can identify any spreading, and treatment is often successful even when cancers have spread to the lymph nodes. For the best thyroid cancer outcomes, your health care team should treat the thyroid and any lymph nodes involved. This usually includes having surgery to remove half or all the thyroid gland. A small number of thyroid cancers are more aggressive than others ‚Äî they may spread faster and have worse outcomes. There are treatments available at UCLA Health for later staged, more aggressive types. No matter the type or stage of thyroid cancer, treatment is crucial. Follow-up after treatment for all patients with thyroid cancer is important since it can come back. If you have questions about your unique cancer, talk to your surgeon and endocrinologist. Learn more about treatment for thyroid cancer: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Surgery for Graves‚Äô Disease | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Grave‚Äôs disease is when the immune system attacks the thyroid gland. This causes the gland to produce too much thyroid hormone (hyperthyroidism). Without treatment, this autoimmune disease can lead to heart failure, heart irregularities and osteoporosis. One treatment option for Grave‚Äôs disease or hyperthyroidism is medication, says endocrine surgeon Avital Harari, MD. If hyperthyroidism continues, treatment with radioactive iodine (RAI) or surgery can help. Surgery for Graves‚Äô disease involves removing half or the entire thyroid (thyroidectomy). To qualify for surgery your thyroid hormone levels need to be under control. After surgery, some people have a raspy voice, which can be temporary or permanent. It‚Äôs possible to have low calcium after surgery but taking calcium supplements can help. There‚Äôs also a risk of bleeding, which sometimes requires another surgery. It‚Äôs wise to discuss your Graves‚Äô disease treatment options with your provider and weigh the pros and cons of each. Find more information about surgery for Graves‚Äô disease: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Normal and Abnormal Calcium Levels | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: Blood tests are often a part of an annual physical exam, and one of the components they measure is the amount of calcium in your blood. Most people have a calcium level in the 8-10 range, but this can vary, says endocrine surgeon Masha Livhits, MD. If your calcium levels are too low, you could have vitamin D deficiency, trouble absorbing calcium from your diet or kidney problems. If your calcium level is high, your doctor will likely recheck it to ensure it wasn‚Äôt a lab error. At UCLA Health, any calcium level above 10.4 is considered high. If your calcium levels are still high after a recheck, more blood tests are needed to determine the cause. For more information, visit the UCLA Health website: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery
caption: false

videoTitle: Side Effects of Radioactive Iodine | UCLA Endocrine Center
videoDescription: For patients with thyroid cancer who have had surgery, radioactive iodine (RAI) treatment can help destroy remaining cancer cells. Common side effects of RAI include dry mouth, swelling and tenderness of the salivary gland, and temporary changes in taste. Other side effects include dry eyes and temporary fertility issues. These should resolve over time, says endocrine surgeon Masha Livhits, MD. Some patients wonder if they can get another cancer, such as leukemia, from the radioactive iodine treatments. Most studies have found less than a one percent chance of developing another cancer from the RAI. Each patient should work with their health care team to determine the risks and benefits of having radioactive iodine treatment. Discuss any concerns or questions you have with your provider ‚Äî they are here to help you make the best treatment decisions possible. Learn more about thyroid cancer treatment, including radioiodine ablation: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/surgery/endocrine-surgery/conditions-treated/thyroid/thyroid-cancer

videoTitle: Neurosurgery Provider - Andrew Vivas | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Dr. Andrew Vivas is a neurosurgeon at UCLA Health who cares for adults and children with spinal deformities. His clinical focus is in the fields of adult and pediatric complex spine surgery, spinal oncology, revision spine surgery and chronic low back pain. Dr. Vivas practices at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center and UCLA Santa Monica Medical Center. He sees patients at a Torrance specialty care clinic and at the UCLA Health Spine Center in Santa Monica. Learn more about Dr. Vivas: https://www.uclahealth.org/providers/andrew-vivas Explore UCLA Health neurosurgery services: https://www.uclahealth.org/medical-services/neurosurgery

videoTitle: 19: Stress, Mental Health, Chronic Inflammation, Belonging, Resiliency l George Slavich, PhD
videoDescription: On this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses how stress and adverse childhood experiences can lead to chronic inflammation and adverse health outcomes with the director of the UCLA Stress lab, Dr. George Slavich. The pair also discuss the sense of belonging, resiliency and the concept of social pain. They further discuss potential therapeutics for stress induced chronic inflammation, including "behavioral psychedelics". For more information on the UCLA Steve Tisch BrainSPORT Program: https://ucla.in/3t6Q77b All episodes are available at https://bit.ly/3I33gVL Connect with us on social. videoTitle: Can Blocking CCR5 Improve Brain Injury and Dementia Recovery?
videoDescription: In this section of the BrainSPORT Podcast Stem Cell episode, Adel and Dr. Carmichael discuss how blocking the CCR5 receptor in the brain can enhance brain injury recovery and even possibly reverse the effects of dementia. videoTitle: Pulsatile Tinnitus & Vascular Diseases | Satoshi Tateshima, MD, DMSc | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Dr. Satoshi Tateshima, a UCLA Health professor in the Division of Interventional Neuroradiology, shares information on pulsatile tinnitus, a type of ear noise that is perceived as rhythmic pulsing, often in-time with the heartbeat, experienced as a thumping or choosing sound. About 1% to 3% of tinnitus patients experience pulsatile tinnitus, and when it experienced, it is almost always a vascular condition ‚Äî not a problem with the ear itself.

videoTitle: 18: How Stem Cells Work, Use in Brain Injury and the CCR5 Receptor l Stanley Carmichael MD, PhD
videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses Stem Cells with the chair of the UCLA Department of Neurology and accomplished stem cell and brain injury research scientist, Dr. Stanley Carmichael. The two discuss what stem cells actually are, how they work and the evidence for their use in brain and spinal cord injury. They further discuss what utilizing stem cells to treat these injuries might look like in the future and current research directions. The pair then shift to discuss Dr. Carmichael's latest work, researching the blockade of the brain's CCR5 receptor. This has demonstrated great potential to enhance brain injury recovery, reverse the effects of dementia and even enhance healthy brain function. For more information on the UCLA Steve Tisch BrainSPORT Program: https://ucla.in/3t6Q77b All episodes are available at https://bit.ly/3I33gVL Connect with us on social. videoTitle: 17: The Dunk Multiple Sclerosis Event: Living & Performing with Multiple Sclerosis and Amazing Dunks
videoDescription: The UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast attends the Dunk Multiple Sclerosis Charity Event. On the episode, Adel talks to former UCLA Men's Basketball player, Blake Arnett, on why he started this event, his goals for the event, and future directions. Adel then sits down with two high profile individuals who are living and thriving with Multiple Sclerosis and speaks with them about how they navigate their diagnosis in the respective high performing professions. The group then check out some of the best basketball dunkers in the country compete in a dunk contest. If you are interested in contributing to advance Multiple Sclerosis research you can donate here: https://ms4ms.org/donate For more information on the UCLA Steve Tisch BrainSPORT Program: https://ucla.in/3t6Q77b All episodes are available at https://bit.ly/3I33gVL Connect with us on social. videoDescription: UCLA Health physicians Dr. Niloofar Nobakht, a nephrologist and kidney specialist, and Dr. Yalda Afashar, a maternal fetal medicine physician, share information on the prevention and management of hypertension in women. videoTitle: 16: Mental Health Crisis, Causes, Solutions, Veterans, Health Care & Injury l Alexander Young, MD
videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses topics relating to mental health with psychiatrist, former chair of the Department of Psychiatry and Biobehavioral Sciences and director of the Semel Institute for Neuroscience & Human Behavior at the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, Alexander Young, MD. Dr. Young is currently associate director of the Veterans Desert Pacific MIRECC Health Services Unit at the Greater Los Angeles Veterans Healthcare System. The pair discuss the mental health crisis occurring in our society today and potential causes relating to it. They cover specific elements of mental health including suicide and PTSD and speak about potential solutions, including earlier diagnosis and treatment. They further discuss mental health in the military veteran population, health care providers, retired athletes, and in those who have suffered brain injuries. If you or someone you know is having thoughts of harming themselves, please call the National Suicide Prevention Hotline at 988 or 1-800-273-8255. videoTitle: Joseph: Laker For A Day
videoDescription: Joseph has been through so much throughout his life. He was born with a heart condition that only has one pumping chamber instead of the normal two, which required multiple heart surgeries. With the support of his family and his doctors at UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital and UCLA Health, Joseph was honored as a Laker For A Day at a game. As a huge Lakers fan, Joseph was beyond excited to get an exclusive tour of the arena, watch warm-ups courtside, and even receive his own jersey. Thank you for being an inspiration to us!

videoTitle: Lung Screening Program: What to expect
videoDescription: Dr. Ashley Prosper, a cardio-thoracic radiologist with UCLA Health, shares information on the UCLA Health Lung Screening Program, including how the process works and what patients can expect when they visit. Low dose CT screening is recommended for patients who are at least 50 years old and have at least a 20 pack-year history of smoking. Low dose CT screening reduces death rates from lung cancer, and early detection usually means that there are more treatment options. More info: uclahealth.org/radiology

videoTitle: 15: Cannabis/Marijuana - Pain, Mental Health, Opioid Epidemic, Adverse Effects & Schedule 1 Status
videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel discusses highly impactful topics on Cannabis with Maddie Katz Professor, Vice-Chair of Clinical Affairs in the UCLA Department of Psychiatry, and former Medical Director of the UCLA Stewart and Lynda Resnick Neuropsychiatric Hospital, Dr. Thomas Strouse. The two discuss the different potential indications for Marijuana use ranging from pain to mental health disorders and brain injury. They talk about the opioid sparing potential and also cover the adverse effects of Cannabis. videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Adel dives into ADHD with UCLA Psychiatrist and ADHD expert Dr. James McGough. The pair discuss the causes and underlying neurobiology of ADHD. They go on to speak about current ADHD treatments, with particular focus on stimulant medications, and the association between ADHD and substance abuse. They finish with a discussion on amphetamine misuse and Dr. McGough's current research. videoDescription: Former NASA astronaut and current Dartmouth Medical School professor of space medicine, Dr. Jay Buckey, presents his personal experience traveling to space as part of the NeuroLab SpaceLab Mission aboard the Columbia shuttle. videoTitle: 12A: The Effect of Long-Term Space Travel on the Brain: Deep Space Radiation
videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, UCSF Adjunct Professor of Neuroscience and Principal Investigator at Altos Labs, Dr. Susanna Rossi, and Adel discuss the effect of deep space travel on the brain. videoTitle: 11B: Non-Invasive Neuromodulation - Enhancing Performance and the "Neuro-Doping" Ethical Concern
videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Harvard Assistant Professor of Neurology and Neuroscientist at the Italian Institute of Technology, Dr. Lorella Batteli, and Adel discuss the use of non-invasive neuromodulation. In Part B, the two talk about how neuromodulation can be used to advance attention during various tasks. They also discuss how the technology can be used to lighten learning curves in sports if used correctly. Dr. Battelli gives her opinion on the moral dilemma that neuromodulation presents for the future of sports. She shares her view on neuromodulation‚Äôs potential adverse side effects as well. The pair conclude by chatting about the future of neuromodulation and where the technology has the potential to go.
