videoTitle: 11A: Non-Invasive Neuromodulation - Neurostimulation, Neuroplasticity and Brain Injury Recovery
videoDescription: In this episode of the UCLA BrainSPORT Podcast, Harvard Assistant Professor of Neurology and Neuroscientist at the Italian Institute of Technology, Dr. Lorella Batteli, and Adel discuss the use of non-invasive neuromodulation. In Part A, the pair first discuss neuromodulation for brain injury and other pathological states. They first focus on Dr. Battelli's research investigating the use of transcranial neuro-stimulation to improve attention and vision following brain injury. They also discuss how neurostimulation actually improves brain injury and the different modalities of neuro-stimulation and their potential benefits, particularly transcranial magnetic stimulation. videoDescription: In Part B, Dr. Mayank Mehta, and Adel discuss the possible ways that virtual reality (VR) can improve performance in several fields. They then dive into the future of a classroom where education is aided by virtual reality. Dr. Mehta emphasizes the brain's unique and powerful response to virtual reality. And finally, Dr. Mehta explains augmented reality, also known as XR, and its ability to show scientists how the brain deciphers what is real and what is not real in the world. For more information on the UCLA Steve Tisch BrainSPORT Program: https://ucla.in/3t6Q77b All episodes are available at https://bit.ly/3I33gVL Connect with us on social. videoTitle: Marisa: Laker For A Day l #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: Meet Marisa Peters, a loving wife and mother of 3, and Head of People at a new tech start-up - VideoAmp. Over a year ago, Marisa was diagnosed with Stage 3 Colorectal Cancer following a checkup related to other health complications. With the support of her both her family, her organization, and UCLA Health, Marisa is on her way to living her best life with her husband and 3 kids. UCLA Health is proud to recognize Marisa as a Laker For A Day! Thank you for being an inspiration to us all. To learn more about what you can do to prevent colorectal cancer, visit: https://www.uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/about

videoTitle: Colorectal Cancer Screening | UCLA Digestive Diseases
videoDescription: A rise in colorectal cancer cases amongst young adults led to new national guidelines lowering the recommended screening age for colorectal cancer from age 50 to 45 (May 2021). Colorectal cancer screening can prevent colorectal cancer through the removal of abnormal growths or polyps. It can also help doctors detect colorectal cancers early when they are most likely curable. Learn more about screening options, when to screen and facts about colorectal cancer at uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/ Presented by Dean Ehrlich, MD and Folasade P. May, MD, PhD, MPhil
caption: false

videoTitle: Scientific Racism: The Influence of Racism in Health Care on Present-day Health Inequities
videoDescription: Harriet A. Washington, award winning author and medical ethicist joins UCLA Health for a conversation on present-day health care inequities. Harriet A. Washington is a prolific science writer, editor and ethicist who is the author of the seminal book: ‚ÄúMedical Apartheid: The Dark History of Experimentation from Colonial Times to the Present‚Äù. This groundbreaking book won a National Book Critics Circle Award, the PEN/Oakland Award, and the American Library Association Black Caucus Nonfiction Award. She is also the author of five other well-received books, including ‚ÄúA Terrible Thing to Waste: Environmental Racism and Its Assault on the American Mind‚Äù as well as the ‚ÄúCarte Blanche: The Erosion of Informed Consent in Medical Research‚Äù, which was published in 2021 by Columbia Global Reports. Event is sponsored by the Black Leadership Coalition and co-sponsored by the Offices of HEDI and JEDI.
tags: Harriet A. Washington,Scientific Racism,health care,inequities,ucla,ucla health

videoTitle: Bowel prep medication options for colonoscopy I UCLA Health
videoDescription: One bowel prep medication for colonoscopy may not be right for everyone. If your prep is not completed properly, you may have to repeat the procedure. Learn more about your colon bowel prep options and get it right the first time! Colorectal cancer is preventable with regular screening that identifies and removes abnormal cell growths or polyps before they become cancer. Learn more at https://www.uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/ Presented by Folasade P. May, MD, PhD
caption: false

videoTitle: Quality initiatives improve colorectal cancer screening rates I UCLA Health
videoDescription: Colorectal cancer screening is a top priority at UCLA Health. We have implemented system-wide quality initiatives that center around getting every eligible adult screened for colorectal cancer. To boost screening rates, we offer a variety of screening options, implemented a fecal immunochemical test (FIT) kit mailing program, involved patient navigators to improve coordination of care for patients with abnormal FIT results, added direct access to colonoscopy and opened new endoscopy units throughout Los Angeles County. Colorectal cancer screening is effective towards colorectal cancer prevention and early detection. Learn more at https://www.uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/ Presented by Folasade P. May, MD, PhD
caption: false

videoTitle: Colorectal cancer risk in African Americans or Black individuals I UCLA Health
videoDescription: African Americans or Black individuals are about 20% more likely to get colorectal cancer and about 40% more likely to die from it than White individuals according to the American Cancer Society (2020). Colorectal cancer is preventable with regular screening that identifies and removes abnormal cell growths or polyps before they become cancer. Learn more at https://www.uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/ Presented by Folasade P. May, MD, PhD
caption: false

videoTitle: Colorectal cancer screening options ‚Äì Pick a test, get it done! I UCLA Health
videoDescription: One in three people is overdue for colorectal cancer screening according to the American Cancer Society (2020). You have many screening test options including colonoscopy and at-home tests. If you are between the ages of 45 and 75, don‚Äôt delay. Colorectal cancer screening is effective towards colorectal cancer prevention and early detection. Pick the test that is best for you, and get it done! Learn more about screening options, when to screen and facts about colorectal cancer at https://www.uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/ Presented by Folasade P. May, MD, PhD
caption: false

videoTitle: Updated colorectal cancer screening recommendations: Start at 45 I UCLA Health
videoDescription: A rise in colorectal cancer cases amongst young adults led to new national guidelines lowering the recommended screening age for colorectal cancer from age 50 to 45 (May 2021). Individuals with a family history of colorectal or high-risk conditions should consult their doctor about whether they should begin screening before age 45. Colorectal cancer screening can prevent colorectal cancer through the removal of abnormal growths or polyps. It can also help doctors detect colorectal cancers early when they are most likely curable. Learn more about screening options, when to screen and facts about colorectal cancer at https://www.uclahealth.org/colon-cancer-screening/ Presented by Folasade P. May, MD, PhD
caption: false

videoTitle: Treating Intractable Infantile Spams: a Serious, Often-Overlooked Condition | Aria Fallah, MD
videoDescription: Aria Fallah, MD, UCLA pediatric surgeon, explains Intractable Infantile Spasms, a condition often overlooked because the symptoms are similar to reflux and colic. Dr. Fallah presents unique symptoms of the condition, important signs and symptoms to look for, how the spasms can lead to seizures, and surgical procedures for treating it. videoDescription: In part A of this episode, Sports Neurologist Adel sits down with UCLA Sports Neuropsychologist Dr. Doug Polster and former NFL Tight End Brandon Bostick to discuss the play that led to Brandon's mental health decline. videoTitle: 5C: What is Functional MRI and how can it be used post-concussion? l Kevin Bickart MD,PhD
videoDescription: In Part C of this episode, UCLA Sports and Behavioral Neurologist Dr. Kevin Bickart and UCLA BrainSPORT Sports Neurologist Adel shift their discussion on Concussion to functional MRI (fMRI) imaging and it's potential to identify post-concussion symptoms. The two discuss what fMRI is and what it measures, how it can be used to identify diseases such as PTSD and OCD, it's potential in identifying post-concussion symptoms, and how this associates to the Autonomic Nervous System, emotional disease states, and potential targeted treatment. videoTitle: What to expect if you're diagnosed with COVID-19
videoDescription: If you are diagnosed with COVID-19, please keep in mind that most people do very well and are able to take care of themselves at home, without ever being hospitalized. This video includes information on how to isolate and care for yourself at home, and what to do if you experience troubling symptoms. If you have questions about COVID-19, UCLA Health has resources and information available at uclahealth.org/coronavirus. You can also reach out to your primary care office with questions or call 310-825-2631 if you need a primary care physician. We are here to help. Content updated January 2022.

videoDescription: In this episode, UCLA Sports and Behavioral Neurologist Dr. Kevin Bickart joins Adel for a discussion on the Autonomic Nervous System and how it is affected by and contributes to Concussions and persistent post-concussion symptoms. videoTitle: The Diller-von Furstenberg Family Endowed Chairs
videoDescription: In 2019, the Diller-von Furstenberg Family Foundation made a generous gift to the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA to establish two endowed chairs - The Diller-von Furstenberg Family Endowed Chair in Human Genetics and The Diller-von Furstenberg Family Endowed Chair in Precision Clinical Genomics. These separate but complementary chairs will help UCLA recruit and retain faculty in these leading-edge disciplines for years to come and help shape the future of genetic research and personalized medicine.

videoDescription: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States, yet too few adults with a history of smoking are undergoing annual lung cancer screenings that can cut death rates by at least 20%. videoTitle: Andy and Tom: A Special Transplant Brings Two Brothers Together
videoDescription: At UCLA Health, we strive to translate science into treatment that brings miracles to life. Through leading-edge research, we're constantly pushing the boundaries to discover the most innovative treatment options for patients. Our devoted surgeons and a team of multidisciplinary experts have developed a revolutionary transplant ‚Äòtolerance‚Äô program to help unlock recipients from the lifelong side effects of immunosuppression. Traditionally, transplant recipients have been burdened by immunosuppressive drugs to prevent their bodies from rejecting their new organ. Today, that‚Äôs all changing. We are pioneering a new way to infuse the donor‚Äôs stem cells into the recipient, significantly reducing or eliminating the need for these drugs. This ‚Äògame-changing‚Äô therapy has transformed two brothers' lives completely. Despite Andy and Tom's distinct personalities, they're a well-matched pair for UCLA Health‚Äôs kidney transplant tolerance program, which enhances transplant patients' lives by freeing them from potent anti-rejection drugs and extending the quality ‚Äòlife-years‚Äô enjoyed from the gift of a transplant. Learn more about our Kidney Transplant Program: https://ucla.in/3nuHguE
tags: UCLA Health,UCLA,Kidney,Transplant,Brotherhood,Transplantation,Immunosuppression-Free,Tolerance,Treatment,Macias Brothers,UCLA tolerance program,UCLA immune tolerance program,Stem cell kidney transplant program,hemapoetic progenitor stem cells,CD-34,combined stem cell kidney transplant,chimerism,Well-matched sibling organ transplant
caption: false

videoTitle: E. Richard Stiehm Endowed Chair in Pediatric Allergy, Immunology and Rheumatology
videoDescription: A renowned immunologist, Dr. E. Richard Stiehm is a distinguished professor emeritus of pediatrics and served as chief of the UCLA Division of Pediatric Allergy, Immunology, and Rheumatology for more than four decades. In 2017, Dr. Stiehm‚Äôs family and Dr. Roger Kobayashi, who trained under Dr. Stiehm, made a generous gift to establish the E. Richard Stiehm Endowed Chair in Pediatric Allergy, Immunology and Rheumatology in celebration of Dr. Stiehm‚Äôs remarkable achievements at UCLA. The chair is held by Dr. Manish Butte, associate professor in the UCLA Department of Pediatrics and Division Chief of Immunology, Allergy, and Rheumatology. Support from the chair enables Dr. Butte to build on Dr. Stiehm‚Äôs legacy through pioneering research and world-class care for children and adults with immune disorders.

videoTitle: Pediatric patients use robot to ‚Äúrun the bases‚Äù at Dodger Stadium
videoDescription: Running the bases at Dodger Stadium is a fun tradition that many children look forward to after most Sunday games. But not all children, especially those who are currently hospitalized or recovering from an illness at home, can physically experience it. That's why UCLA Health, the Dodgers and OhmniLabs teamed up to create a virtual run-the-bases experience for 10 pediatric patients at UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital. With the help of the Ohmni Robot, controlled via a computer, phone or tablet from the safety of one's hospital bed or home, these patients got the opportunity to move the robot around the bases on the field. The robot's video chat function also allowed the patients to meet a few Dodger players, including Edwin Rios, Gavin Lux and Mitch White.

videoTitle: Chai-Chih: Laker for a Day | #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: Fifteen years ago, Chai-Chih Huang, MSN, RN, began spending her vacation time volunteering with humanitarian medical missions across the globe. She‚Äôs been to Nepal, China, Haiti, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Ecuador. Huang, UCLA Health‚Äôs director of pediatric nursing, loves the international work so much she intends to dedicate herself to it full time when she retires. The COVID-19 pandemic put a halt to trips abroad in 2020. And then came 2021 ‚Äì and in a surprise development, Huang found herself working full time on an international humanitarian mission right here at home. In April, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services tapped UCLA Health to provide medical care for unaccompanied migrant children from Central America at a new federal shelter at the Long Beach Convention Center. In less than 24 hours, UCLA Health workers set up an urgent care clinic, pharmacy, medical exam rooms and a COVID-19 isolation unit inside the empty convention center, along with a secure computer network to establish and track health records for every child. Huang has been overseeing nursing efforts at the emergency-intake site since it opened, caring for the more than 700 children who have passed through the center. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing: We went from zero workload, zero protocol, to the robust infrastructure we have now,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what makes me so proud of UCLA. For sure, this is the highlight of my career, that I get to experience all this.‚Äù Read the fully story here: https://bit.ly/3walmyE

videoTitle: Grey Matters: The Developing Brain
videoDescription: The UCLA Neuroscience Research Theme presents Grey Matters: The Developing Brain. The human brain contains about 100 billion neurons connected to each other by over 100 trillion connections. There is an extraordinary diversity of neurons with different functions and these are connected to each other in very specific ways. The structure and function of the brain, indeed who we are, reflects the interplay between genetic programs and our experiences during childhood and adolescence. Panelists discussed exciting new developments in this field, the genetic basis of neuropsychiatric disorders, and how our experiences change the structure and function of our brains. This webinar was recorded on April 29, 2021 and featured Dean Kelsey Martin, M.D., Ph.D., Larry Zipursky, Ph.D., Aparna Bhaduri, Ph.D., Joshua Trachtenberg, Ph.D., Daniel Geschwind, M.D., Ph.D., Adriana Galv√°n, Ph.D.

videoTitle: UCLA Kid Captain: 'Unluckiest Family in the Whole Entire World'
videoDescription: Read Ava, Olivia, and Landon's story and experience as UCLA Football's Kid Captains: https://bit.ly/3kD3wz8 Olivia Langenhop, the fourth child in the world to undergo treatment offered only at UCLA for her deadly genetic disorder, gleefully waved a blue pom-pom a week after leaving the hospital. During a special Zoom call with the Bruins football team in December, Olivia, 3, sat between the second and third patients to ever receive that same gene therapy ‚Äì treatment for a rare disorder called Leukocyte adhesion deficiency-1, which hobbles the immune system. Olivia laughed and played with the other kids, who happened to be her older sister, Ava, 5, and baby brother, Landon, 1. In a celebratory moment for the siblings, they served as honorary Kid Captains for the Dec. 12 game against USC.

videoTitle: Fecal Immunochemical Test (FIT) for Colon Cancer Screening | UCLA Digestive Diseases
videoDescription: A fecal immunochemical test (FIT) is colon cancer screening option that patients can perform from home. Most FIT kits include the following: outer envelope, sampling bottle, collection paper, question and answer brochure, return mailer envelope, biohazard bag, absorbant pad. videoTitle: STAT Madness - Dr. Weizhe Hong | UCLA Health
videoDescription: It's time to fill out your March Madness bracket...not for basketball, but for research! UCLA Health is among 64 institutions nationwide selected to compete for the most innovative research of the year in a competition organized by STAT news. Dr. Weizhe Hong of UCLA Health entered this competition and studied how our brains shape with social interaction. By using advanced imaging techniques, he and his team recorded activity in two interacting animals at the same time. They discovered their brains became synchronized, providing new insight into fundamental brain processes that shape social interaction. Vote for Dr. Hong today: https://www.statnews.com/feature/stat-madness/bracket/ #VoteUCLAHealth

videoTitle: Surviving sudden death syndrome | UCLA Health Newsroom
videoDescription: Ed was a graduate student playing basketball at the UCLA recreation center when he experienced sudden cardiac arrest, known as sudden death syndrome. He survived this rare and often deadly condition thanks to a few bystanders who used an external defibrillator and CPR on him. He‚Äôs back to playing basketball, now runs his own company, and has an implanted defibrillator in place to prevent another cardiac arrest. He says he‚Äôs grateful for a second chance at life. For more information, visit UCLA Heart and Vascular Services at https://www.uclahealth.org/heart/

videoTitle: Telemedicine-Aided Therapy Helps Parents of Children With Developmental Disorders, Including Autism
videoDescription: For families of children with developmental disorders, access to early intervention programs can make a huge difference in their overall development. However, many families in smaller cities or rural areas do not have convenient access to such programs, often located at larger universities in big cities. To address that need, researchers at UCLA are using telemedicine to remotely help families learn skills that let them work at home with their children to gain essential social skills. One such study involves children with tuberous sclerosis, a rare genetic disorder that often causes development issues. Scientists found early signs of autism in this group of infants who, until now, would never have received crucial early intervention. Read the full article here: https://ucla.in/2uppOPo
tags: UCLA Health,Autism,Developmental Disorders,Telemedicine,tuberous sclerosis
caption: false

videoDescription: Kidney Cancer Program receives gift for research on genetic forms of kidney cancer UCLA Health‚Äôs Kidney Cancer Program received $102,483 from Driven to Cure, a nonprofit organization dedicated to advocacy and providing funding for research on rare genetic forms of kidney cancer. The gift will support physician-researcher Brian Shuch, MD, an associate professor of urology at the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA. The support will facilitate a collaboration between the cancer research labs at UCLA‚Äôs Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center in disciplines such as tumor metabolism, molecular biology, cancer genomics and population health. videoTitle: Kid Captain: Jackson Verner
videoDescription: Sara Verner tried to keep it together as her 5-year-old son Jackson lived out his dream as UCLA Kid Captain for the Bruins‚Äô matchup with Oklahoma at the Rose Bowl. But seeing the unbridled joy on her son‚Äôs face and the spring in his step as he bounded from one tailgate event to the next, roamed the sidelines during pre-game warm-ups, and took to the field for an introduction that earned him a standing ovation from the crowd of more than 50,000, Verner struggled to hold her emotions in check. ‚ÄúIt was really hard not to cry the whole time, to be honest,‚Äù she says. Jackson Verner has spent much of his young life as a hospital inpatient. After Jackson suffered a series of strokes in 2017 that paralyzed the entire left side of his body, doctors told Sara Verner that her son would need at least six months of in-hospital rehabilitation and might never regain his full gait, if he could walk at all. ‚ÄúI said no, he‚Äôll walk out of here, I promise,‚Äù Verner recalls. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know this kid.‚Äù Read Jackson‚Äôs story and see photos of Jackson as UCLA Football‚Äôs Kid Captain: https://ucla.in/2N7MxFA

videoTitle: Schedule a Mammogram to Detect Breast Cancer Early | UCLA Health & Circle of Health
videoDescription: Routine care is the best way to keep you and your breasts healthy. Early detection decreases breast cancer deaths. The American College of Radiology recommends annual mammogram screening beginning at age 40 for women of average risk. Higher-risk women should start mammographic screening earlier and may benefit from supplemental screening modalities. Learn more about mammograms at https://www.uclahealth.org/breasthealth/

videoTitle: Preparing for Your Colonoscopy | UCLA Health Digestive Diseases
videoDescription: A colonoscopy is a procedure that allows your doctor to examine the inside of your lower digestive tract, also known as your colon and rectum. The procedure uses a colonoscope (‚Äúscope‚Äù) ‚Äî a long flexible tube with a light and camera at the end ‚Äî to examine the inside lining of the colon. It allows the doctor performing the test to find and remove precancerous polyps and early colon cancers. The day before the test, you will do a bowel prep to empty and clean your colon. Learn more: https://ucla.in/2LxPJLN Video shared with permission from the American Gastroenterological Association
tags: preparing for colonoscopy,how to prepare for colonoscopy,how does colonoscopy work,before colonoscopy
caption: false

videoTitle: Stop the Bleed | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Did you know that trauma is the fourth leading cause of death in America and bleeding is the #1 cause of preventable death following injury? This, despite the fact that nearly anyone can control life threatening bleeding. All you need are your hands, and a little know-how. In an emergency, get help. Call 911 or get another person to do so. Find the source of the bleeding and cover the wound with a cloth or an article of clothing and apply direct, steady, pressure with both hands until help arrives. If the person is unconscious, lay them on their side with the wound up if possible. Once the bleeding is under control, just make sure the injured person is breathing well and comfortable. If you can‚Äôt stop the bleeding with continuous direct pressure, you can apply a tourniquet. Applying a tourniquet requires another person to help and should only be done as a last resort. To learn more about additional hands-on training, visit the UCLA Center for Prehospital Care at https://www.cpc.mednet.ucla.edu/ Learn more at https://www.uclahealth.org/
tags: life threatening bleeding,emergency,stop the bleed,stopping bleeding in an emergency,UCLA Center for Prehospital Care
caption: true

videoTitle: Tips for Calling 911 | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Would it blow your mind to know that 240 million people a year dial 911? How about if almost half of those calls weren‚Äôt even necessary? That‚Äôs bad, because it keeps them from being able to help real emergencies. Now if you are calling about a real emergency, first thing is to stay as calm as you can.These are trained professionals and they use a series of questions to get you the right assistance in the shortest time...so just listen and answer. And they might ask you more questions, so if you know the answers it‚Äôs really helpful. You could also be asked to describe someone‚Äôs symptoms, so get in there and do the best you can. Even if you or someone else accidentally dials 911...don‚Äôt hang up. The 911 Dispatcher might think you tried to call but couldn‚Äôt and again, big waste of their time and resources. Remember, anytime you are not comfortable with a medical situation, you should call for help. By acting quickly, you may prevent a serious emergency and could save a life.
tags: emergency,save a life,when calling 911,Calling 911,Calling 911 in an emergency
caption: true

videoTitle: CPR Saves Lives | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is given when someone's breathing or pulse stops. If both have stopped, then sudden death has occurred. Some of the causes of sudden death include poisoning, drowning, choking, suffocation, electrocution, or smoke inhalation. But, the most common cause of sudden death is from heart attack. Despite the fact that CPR is proven to save lives ‚Äî patient recovery rates are better when bystanders initiate resuscitation and there‚Äôs a greater likelihood of survival with less damage to heart muscles and the brain ‚Äî studies suggest that less than one-third of people experiencing cardiac arrest outside of a medical center receive the help they need. If you or someone you know has any of the above warning signs, act immediately. Call 911, or your local emergency number. If needed, give CPR if you are trained, or ask someone who is. Learn more at https://www.uclahealth.org/cpr
tags: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation,CPR,medical emergency,how to do CPR,Hands only CPR
caption: true

videoTitle: Harlow & Pierre: Laker Dogs For A Day | #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: They say every dog has his day but only two dogs can say they‚Äôve been Lakers for a Day. Harlow, a Golden Retriever/Lab mix, and Pierre, a French Bull Dog, received the honor in recognition of the UCLA People-Animal Connection (PAC). This program involves more than 60 dogs who, supervised by their human partners, bring warmth, companionship and the occasional lick to children and adults receiving care at UCLA. One of the most comprehensive Animal-Assisted Therapy and Activity programs in the nation, PAC has provided more than 120,000 in-patient visits since its inception in 1994. The highly trained and screened dogs ‚Äì and one miniature horse ‚Äì have a special way of bonding with patients of all ages, cultures and socioeconomic levels. They ‚Äúhelp transport our patients and families away from a state of illness and anxiety to a place of feeling happy and engaged,‚Äù says Erin Rice, director of the PAC program. Harlow and her owner, Debbie, and Pierre and his owner, Matt, received an exclusive tour of the UCLA Health Training Center, where the Lakers train (although the canine pair did more sniffing than looking). Harlow and Pierre also showed some love to the Lakers staff. The following week, the four attended a Laker game. Harlow and Pierre got lots of belly rubs from the Laker Girls and had their own grass patch in the concourse where they got to meet fans and pose for pictures. During the game, Harlow and Pierre were brought to center court and honored as Lakers for a Day. #TeamUCLALakers
tags: UCLA Health,PAC,People Animal Connection,Therapy Animals,Therapy Dogs,UCLA,Lakers,Laker For A Day,Los Angeles Lakers,UCLA Medical Center,Community,Pierre,Harlow,UCLA Health PAC,Dogs,Puppies,Maya Rudolph,Laker Game,Therapy,Wellness,Labrador,French Bull Dog,Pierre Dont Care

Established in 1975, the UCLA Mobile Eye Clinic is one of the first programs of its kind and the longest continuously operating eye clinic on wheels. The mobile clinic travels through Los Angeles‚Äô diverse neighborhoods to reach those with the greatest need. Eye exams are performed to determine the need for prescriptive lenses and to rule out the need for further treatment of any eye condition or disease. The Mobile Eye Clinic makes visits to schools, preschools, free clinics, community centers and agencies that serve the homeless and low-income families. Learn more about the UCLA Mobile Eye Clinic at https://www.uclahealth.org/mobile-eye-clinic/

videoTitle: Willow: Laker Girl For A Day | #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: Willow Crisostomo‚Äôs middle name, Lux, means light in Latin. At five years old, she is a bright light of smiles, love and curiosity. But Willow‚Äôs future looked dim when she was born at less than 23 weeks, about half the length of a normal gestation. Just 14 ounces, Willow weighed about the same as a football. Her parents, Stephanie and Joseph, who live in Bakersfield, were told that Willow had only a five percent chance of surviving. She had serious respiratory issues and needed surgery to correct a heart defect. Stephanie and Joseph decided to put their trust in the UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital NICU (Neonatal Intensive Care Unit) After four months in the NICU, Willow was finally strong enough to go home. Her parents were grateful for the care they received at UCLA. ‚ÄúEveryone from the doctors to the respiratory therapists to the housekeeping staff made us feel like we were taken care of and a vital part of Willow‚Äôs team,‚Äù said Stephanie. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a place that exemplifies a culture of care,‚Äù said Joseph. Willow, her sister, parents and grandparents visited the UCLA Health Training Center and spent a day touring the facility. Willow met two Laker Girls who presented her with her own Laker Girls outfit and practiced some cheers with her. Willow couldn‚Äôt have been happier as she learned dances and cheers with the girls. Her presence really lit up the floor. Two weeks later, the family returned for a Lakers game, dining in the Chairman‚Äôs Lounge and hanging out with the Laker Girls during the game. It was a great day for a sunny little girl and her family. During a timeout, Willow and some of the Laker Girls took the floor for her recognition. Willow was the star of the game.
tags: Lakers,NICU,Courage,TeamUCLALakers,UCLA Health,Health,Pediatric,UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital,Mattel,UCLA,UCLA Health Training Center,Willow,Family,Community,Care

videoTitle: Kid Captain Vivian! l UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Vivian has a purple belt in karate, enjoys singing and dancing to Katy Perry songs and loves to color. She also has a heart of gold, organizing a toy drive at her preschool and presenting the donations to UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital and the UCLA Children‚Äôs Heart Center in hopes that pediatric patients would enjoy them just as much as she enjoyed the toys provided during her stay. Getting to this point has not been easy for Vivian, who was born with a complex congenital heart defect. At just 10 days old, she had open-heart surgery and spent the first six months of her life in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. She has had multiple surgeries and cardiac interventions since. Through it all, Vivian‚Äôs spirit has never wavered. The courage and perseverance she displayed during her treatment helped earn her UCLA Kid Captain honors for the Bruins‚Äô football season opener against Cincinnati on Sept. 1 at the Rose Bowl. ‚ÄúVivian is very excited to be Kid Captain. It‚Äôs as if she‚Äôs conquering the whole world,‚Äù said her mother, Judy. Vivian was joined at the game by her parents, twin sister, younger brother, grandparents and aunt as well as her cardiologist, Mark Sklansky, MD, Chief of Pediatric Cardiology and Medical Director at the Children‚Äôs Heart Center. The group was escorted to the Bruin Game Day tent before the game, then walked over to the UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital kid zone, complete with bounce houses for children to explore. Vivian and her family also watched warm-ups on the field and met Joe and Josie Bruin, the school‚Äôs mascots. She also spent time with the cheerleading team, receiving a cheerleading outfit that was her favorite, and was recognized on the field during a break in the game. ‚ÄúI love being Kid Captain!‚Äù Vivian said.

videoTitle: Donovan: Laker for a Day | #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: As he posed for a family photo near half court, one of Donovan‚Äôs favorite players walked up behind him. ‚ÄúWhich one of you is Donovan?‚Äù asked Lakers forward Kyle Kuzma. Donovan stared in awe as Kuzma pulled out custom Lakers jerseys for him and his siblings. They all put on their jerseys and played HORSE on the team‚Äôs practice court. Kuzma made things easy at first, then turned up the competitiveness to seal a friendly win against Donovan and his family. Of course, Donovan has scored his share of victories. That he could even participate in such a moment with a member of his beloved Lakers is proof enough. Donovan was born with pulmonary atresia, a type of heart disease in which the pulmonary valve does not form properly. He counts three open-heart surgeries and five stint surgeries among the health hurdles he has overcome, so it‚Äôs easy to see why he enjoyed being the UCLA Health Laker for a Day so much. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been a Lakers fan ever since I could remember,‚Äù says Donovan. As part of his Laker for a Day experience, Donovan had an amazing time at the UCLA Health Training Center ‚Äì the home of the Lakers. He watched practice with his brothers Duncan, Brody and Isaiah as well as one of his sisters, Frankie, and their parents, Inez and Mike. The Lakers had more than one surprise for Donovan. They first brought Donovan to the court to watch the end of their practice, where he met and took pictures with Lakers coach Luke Walton and 7-footer JaVale McGee. The Lakers invited Donovan and his family to shoot around on the same floor where the team had just practiced, and that‚Äôs when Kuzma came out of the locker room for the jersey surprise. The family also received a tour of the team‚Äôs headquarters. Their favorite part was seeing the sparkling championship rings outside of Lakers owner Jeanie Buss‚Äô office, where they debated which ring had the most diamonds in it. Donovan arrived early to the Lakers‚Äô game against Phoenix on Jan. 27, watching warm ups and getting to hang out in the Chairman‚Äôs Lounge for dinner. The fans applauded Donovan when the video of his story played during an on-court presentation, a moment Donovan and his family will always cherish. ‚ÄúHe always says to me, ‚ÄòI got to do well. I shouldn‚Äôt be living, so I got to make the best of my life,‚Äô‚Äù says Donovan‚Äôs father, Mike. ‚ÄúI go, ‚ÄòWell, you will.‚Äô‚Äù
tags: Lakers,UCLA Health,#TeamUCLALakers,TeamUCLALakers,Heart,Heart Month,Basketball,Kuzma,Kyle Kuzma,Kuzmania,Health,Laker For A Day,Community
caption: false

videoTitle: Lullaby-Playing Pacifier Helps Premature Babies Thrive | UCLA Health Newsroom
videoDescription: Babies who are born premature often struggle with feeding and the reflex to suck, breathe and swallow, which is pivotal for their development. And when parents watch their premature newborns in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), they often feel helpless. Now, researchers with the music therapy program at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital are testing whether an unusual device, which plays a lullaby recorded by the baby‚Äôs parents when a baby successfully sucks on the connected pacifier, can empower parents by helping them bond with their babies -- and strengthen the babies by improving their oral abilities, which play a crucial role in the ability to feed. A family with triplets participated in the research and used the pacifier-activated lullaby (PAL) device to aid in their babies‚Äô development. Learn more about the music therapy program at https://ucla.in/2lrCgoz
tags: premature baby,neonatal services,premature newborn,neonatal intensive care unit,NICU,music therapy program,UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital,pacifier-activated lullaby,pacifier-activated lullaby device,PAL Device

videoTitle: Shebyon: Laker For A Day | #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: Shebyon Bedgood has had a lifetime‚Äôs worth of hospital visits. She was diagnosed with juvenile diabetes as a youngster, received a kidney transplant as an adult and later developed urinary tract infections, among other complications. Despite enduring so much already, Shebyon had to overcome yet another major health hurdle: breast cancer. Shebyon has endured through it all, and her perseverance earned her special recognition as a UCLA Health Laker For A Day honoree this December. But all she ever really wanted was to be healthy enough to spend time with her sister, two daughters and three grandchildren, and so of course she used the opportunity to include them in the experience. ‚ÄúYou can have all the money in the world. You can have all the things in the world ‚Äì all the fancy cars, all the homes. But if you ain‚Äôt got health, you don‚Äôt have nothing,‚Äù she said. Shebyon‚Äôs family pushed her to seek better care and proved to be the catalyst in her turnaround. When she came to UCLA Health, she was introduced to 11 different specialists, all independently treating her with a variety of antibiotics and medications. Then, last year, UCLA Health launched an initiative for patients with complex conditions called the Extensivist Program, which helped Shebyon receive the comprehensive care she sought. ‚ÄúIf I had the other plan, I know I wouldn‚Äôt be here,‚Äù she said. The program brings a group of specialists together to produce a unified care plan. The team includes a primary care physician, medical oncologist, endocrinologist, urologist and students from the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA. ‚ÄúWe went from fractured care, to complete care,‚Äù said Shebyon‚Äôs sister, Angela Burrell. Shebyon‚Äôs Laker For A Day experience began with what she wanted most: time with her family. Shebyon hosted a family barbecue that included Dr. Sun Yoo, her primary care physician and medical director of the Extensivist Program, and Kevin Noel, care coordinator for the Extensivist Program. As the barbecue ended, they surprised Shebyon with a custom Lakers jersey, three LeBron James jerseys for her grandchildren, and four tickets to the Lakers game against the Phoenix Suns on Dec. 2. Shebyon brought her sister, brother-in-law and her grandson Javaras, who was celebrating his birthday, to the game. The crowd reception was nothing short of amazing when Shebyon took the floor and shared her story. Javaras also competed in the Half Minute to Win It Challenge ‚Äì an on-court shooting challenge that gives a young fan a chance to earn a scholarship to Camp Lakers, presented by UCLA Health. To top it off, Shebyon met Hall of Famer Bill Russell and enjoyed a Lakers win! Learn more at https://ucla.in/2rM2iXX
tags: Laker For A Day,UCLA Health,Los Angeles Lakers,Lakers,Extensivist,UCLA,Breast Cancer,Diabetes,Healthcare
caption: false

videoTitle: Nigel : Laker for a Day | #TeamUCLALakers
videoDescription: Nigel has come a long way in the last three years to become the strong 10-year-old he is today. In 2015, Nigel was having difficulty breathing, so his parents took him to the emergency room. Doctors discovered Nigel had a large tumor in his kidney, also known as a Wilms tumor. Doctors removed Nigel‚Äôs kidney, and he endured many round of chemotherapy following the procedure. Nigel learned his cancer had returned after tests showed he had an elevated white blood count that led to his diagnosis of leukemia, which required a bone marrow transplant; Dr. Ted Moore and his team at UCLA were on top of it. Nigel‚Äôs first match for a transplant never materialized, so Nigel‚Äôs father stepped up as a haplo match, or half match. As he recovered, Nigel was unable to attend school and lacked the energy to hang out with his friends. Luckily, he could play interactive video games where he could communicate with his friends. When asked how he processed his diagnosis, Nigel said, ‚ÄúI just try to be positive all the time and stay happy.‚Äù Nigel‚Äôs fight, determination and maturity is an inspiration to both UCLA Health and the Lakers family, earning him Laker For A Day honors. In early October, Nigel was invited to have an exclusive look at the UCLA Health Training Center: Home of the Los Angeles Lakers. The facility is where the Lakers train, practice and hang out when they are not playing games. All of the Lakers staff work out of the building as well. During the tour, Nigel and his family got to enjoy some time in the office of team owner Jeanie Buss. They were amazed by seeing their own reflection in the 10 NBA championship trophies that line the windows overlooking the practice court. As he prepared to share his story to a video crew, Nigel jokingly said: ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm getting ready to be interviewed by Bryant Gumbel.‚Äù Nigel got the full tour of the facility, from the offices to the court. The Lakers even had a special surprise for him. As Nigel walked into the players‚Äô locker room, he saw plaques above each locker that read, [Lebron] James, [Lonzo] Ball, [Kyle] Kuzma, [Rajon] Rondo ‚Ä¶ and then he saw his last name stitched on one of the jerseys! The Lakers presented Nigel with his own Lakers locker along with the custom uniform so he could truly look the part of a Laker For A Day. He raced to put on the uniform and took the court for a shootaround with his dad, Brian. At the game, Nigel received an on-court recognition which caught his newest fan‚Äôs eye: actor Denzel Washington. As Nigel walked off the court to a standing ovation, Washington asked the UCLA Health Laker For A Day for a picture. Nigel left the arena with more than enough stories to share with his friends at school all week.

videoTitle: Kid Captain Bibiana | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Bibiana "Bibi" spent the first three-and-a-half years of her life on dialysis until receiving a kidney transplant at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. Bibi and her parents know she will likely need another transplant someday, but that doesn‚Äôt get her down. ‚ÄúShe takes it like a trooper,‚Äù says her father, Patrick. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs able to persevere. She has special needs and people see that, but she doesn‚Äôt let that stop her.‚Äù Bibi still comes for doctor visits at the hospital, and her parents consider UCLA Health family. As big Los Angeles sports fans, it was extra special for Bibi to be honored as Kid Captain for the Bruins‚Äô football game against Arizona at the Rose Bowl on Oct. 20. Bibi joined the UCLA Health employee tailgate, where she mixed and mingled with more than 400 people. She also watched warmups from the field, getting closer to the action than she had ever been. ‚ÄúKid Captain is an opportunity for her to know there are more options out there than just being home,‚Äù says her mother, Rosa. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a big world that she doesn‚Äôt know yet.‚Äù

videoTitle: Staff Sergeant Octavio Sanchez shares his story | UCLA Operation Mend
videoDescription: Marine Staff Sergeant Octavio Sanchez was the victim of a makeshift roadside bomb in Ramadi and suffered third-degree burns over 70 percent of his face and body. Before arriving at the V.A.-Greater Los Angeles, he was told there was nothing more that could be done for him. UCLA Operation Mend doctors were able to construct a nose, using skin from SSgt Sanchez's forehead. Once the blood supply was in place, one of his ribs was implanted to provide structure to the nose. Nostrils were fashioned out of remaining ear cartilage and his lips and cheeks were rebuilt. He has undergone several surgeries on his face and hand and now enjoys a more natural and normal appearance. Learn more: http://operationmend.ucla.edu/
tags: operation mend,marine staff sargeant octavio sanchez,plastic surgery,veteran services,ucla veteran programs

videoTitle: Skye's Story | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Each year, over 250,000 new cases of cancer affect children under the age of 20 worldwide. While the survival rate for many childhood cancers has significantly increased, two-thirds of childhood cancer patients will have long-term side effects and chronic conditions from their life-saving treatments. Despite these statistics, childhood cancer research is widely underfunded. The Pediatric Hematology Oncology division is committed to research to find cures for childhood cancer, to find effective treatments for disease and to improving and extending the life of our patients and their families. Division Chief, Dr. Theodore Moore, and Dr. Theodore Scott Nowicki, are joined by parents Talia and Todd Savern-McCormick with their daughter Skye to share their experience at UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital. Learn more at https://www.uclahealth.org/mattel/Pediatric-Hematology-Oncology/
tags: childhood cancer,childhood cancers,UCLA Pediatric Hematology Oncology,Dr. Theodore Moore,Dr. Theodore Scott Nowicki,Pediatric cancer,cancer in childeren,pediatric cancer research,childhood cancer research

videoTitle: UVAS Enhancing Value in Health Care: It Takes a System | UCLA Value-Based Care Research Consortium
videoDescription: Dr. Eve Kerr, a nationally recognized leader in healthcare quality and value, delivers the keynote at UCLA‚Äôs Value-Based Care Research Consortium Kickoff. Drawing from decades of research and practice, Dr. Kerr discusses the urgent need to reduce low-value care, presents evidence from major studies across the VA and Medicare systems, and emphasizes the importance of system-level transformation, innovation and community collaboration. She also shares her personal journey from UCLA trainee to national leader and highlights opportunities to drive meaningful change through patient-centered, high-value care.
caption: false

videoTitle: UVAS Remarks by Dr. Alan Fogelman | UCLA Value-Based Care Research Consortium 2018
videoDescription: In this brief session, Dr. Alan Fogelman, Chair of UCLA‚Äôs Department of Medicine, offers opening remarks for the afternoon panel on value-based care in practice. He praises the effort behind the conference, highlights UCLA Health‚Äôs ongoing work to become an integrated health system, and underscores the complexity of implementing value-based care effectively. Using colorectal cancer screening as an example, he illustrates the gap between offering cost-effective care (like FIT tests) and ensuring follow-through (like completing a colonoscopy after a positive result). He emphasizes the need for innovative thinking and continued commitment to tackle these real-world challenges.
caption: false

videoTitle: UVAS Welcome and Opening Remarks | UCLA Value-Based Care Research Consortium 2018
videoDescription: This video features the kickoff event for UCLA's Value-Based Care Research Consortium, led by Dr. Katherine Sarkissian. The symposium brings together clinicians, researchers, and community partners to discuss the consequences of low-value care, highlight innovative interventions, and foster cross-disciplinary collaboration. Through real patient stories and impactful data, the event emphasizes the need for smarter, more equitable healthcare.
caption: false

videoTitle: UVAS Panel on Advancing Value-Based Care Research | UCLA Value-Based Care Research Consortium 2018
videoDescription: This panel brings together experts from UCLA, RAND, USC, and UC Health to discuss advancing value-based care. Topics include behavioral nudges, low-value care measurement, system-level data use, and the need for better patient-centered outcomes. Panelists emphasize multidisciplinary collaboration, aligning incentives, and improving data infrastructure to drive change. The session closes with a dynamic audience Q&A on trade-offs, EMR limitations and structural barriers in a profit-driven healthcare system.
caption: false

videoTitle: UVAS Panel on Translational and Implementation Science | UCLA Value Based Care Research Consortium
videoDescription: This session focuses on translating value-based care research into real-world healthcare improvements across UC health systems. Panelists from UCLA, Cedars-Sinai, UCSF and the VA share diverse approaches, including shared decision-making, integrating palliative care into oncology clinics, and using centralized electronic health record (EHR) data to reduce variation in care. The discussion emphasizes implementation challenges, cost transparency, engaging frontline clinicians, and leveraging data analytics for personalized, cost-effective treatment strategies, particularly in managing chronic conditions like diabetes.
caption: false

videoTitle: New Therapies Cut Seizures in People with Drug-Resistant Epilepsy | UCLA Health
videoDescription: Sharon Shafer is one of 1 million Americans with drug-resistant epilepsy. She tried 12 medications in 14 years, but nothing stopped her seizures. Finally she discovered the UCLA Seizure Disorder Center, where doctors recommended responsive neurostimulation, or RNS‚Äîthe first ‚Äúsmart therapy‚Äù for epilepsy. Surgically implanted under the skull, the small device senses oncoming seizures and issues a brief electrical pulse to stop them in their tracks. Experts encourage patients to consult a full-service epilepsy center like UCLA‚Äôs, where RNS is just one approach in the arsenal of tools for controlling seizures.
tags: seizures,neurostimulation,UCLA Seizure Disorder Center,epilepsy,seizure therapy,electrical pulse,epilepsy center

videoTitle: Music therapy study on the NICU | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: A program that provides music therapy for patients at UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital is expanding by adding two music therapy fellows who will assist patients and new research beginning in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) over the course of a year. As part of the expansion, UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital also will be conducting research in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) to evaluate how personalized lullabies and parents' recorded voices can help premature babies improve their ability to properly feed and suckle, build their endurance and reduce their perception of pain. The research will include the use of a device called a pacifier-activated lullaby (PAL). Learn more: https://www.uclahealth.org/mattel/music-therapy-internship

videoTitle: Kid Captain Gabby | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: At the age of 2, Gabby Yambo experienced a six-hour seizure that nearly claimed her life. After rushing her to the hospital, Gabby‚Äôs parents learned that their daughter was suffering from a rare brain disease called hemimegalencephaly (HME). Due to a structural abnormality in her brain, Gabby was experiencing constant seizures, sometimes up to 300 a day. Over the next 13 years, Gabby underwent two brain surgeries at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital to remove the part of her brain causing her seizures. Gabby, now 14, has been seizure-free since her latest procedure with UCLA pediatric neurosurgeon Aria Fallah, MD, in 2017. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know many people who would have survived what she‚Äôs been through and been as strong as she‚Äôs been through it all,‚Äù Gabby‚Äôs father Rick Yambo says. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my hero.‚Äù To honor her strength and courage, Gabby has been named a UCLA Kid Captain. ‚ÄúBeing UCLA Kid Captain is a great opportunity for her to celebrate,‚Äù says Gabby‚Äôs mother Krista McFall Yambo. ‚ÄúShe loves being around people, she loves celebrating, having fun, dancing and [listening to] music. And for her to do some celebrating is a great day.‚Äù

videoTitle: Rhianna's Journey with Chiari Malformation | UCLA Pediatric Neurosurgery
videoDescription: Teenager Rhianna Wilson spent her senior year of high school in and out of four San Diego hospitals, seeking relief for her vision loss, leg pain and debilitating headaches. She was diagnosed with Ehler-Danlos Syndrome (EDS), a genetic disorder marked by overly stretchy connective tissue, but no one could explain what caused her worsening symptoms. Doctors encouraged Rhianna‚Äôs parents to consider a seeing-eye dog and enroll her in a school for the blind. Her mother‚Äôs research led her to UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital, where pediatric neurosurgeon Dr. Aria Fallah referred Rhianna for a stand-up MRI. The scan revealed a large Chiari malformation, a rare condition in which the brain slips downward and compresses the spinal column. Dr. Fallah removed Rhianna‚Äôs top vertebra and the back bone of her skull, creating more space for her brain and relieving her symptoms. When Rhianna opened her eyes after surgery, she could see again. In less than three weeks, she was living like a typical teenager: driving, working, hiking and enjoying the active social life she‚Äôd missed during her senior year. Learn more: https://ucla.in/2qwXyGZ
tags: ucla pediatric neurosurgery,neurosurgery,pediatric neurosurgery,rhianna story,chiari malformation,best brain surgeon los angeles,rare brain disorder treatment,best neurosurgeon los angeles,Ehlers-Danlos syndrome,Ehlers-Danlos syndrome treatment,how to treat Ehlers-Danlos syndrome,genetic disorders,hypermobility

videoTitle: New App Tells Deaf Parents When And Why Their Baby Is Crying | UCLA Health News
videoDescription: The ChatterBaby app uses machine learning to analyze babies‚Äô cries Parents can often tell what their baby needs simply by the sound of their cry. But what if you couldn‚Äôt hear your child‚Äôs cry? That‚Äôs a challenge deaf and hearing-impaired parents live with every day, but a new app could help overcome that challenge. The ChatterBaby app not only lets deaf parents know when their baby is crying, it also can tell them why they‚Äôre crying. ‚ÄúThe app analyzes the different types of frequencies that are in the cry and the different patterns of sound and silence,‚Äù said Ariana Anderson, PhD, assistant professor in residence at the UCLA Semel Institute who spearheaded the development of the app. ‚ÄúFor example, if a cry has a long period of silence, it‚Äôs more likely that the baby is fussy. If there are constant, high-volume frequencies, it‚Äôs more likely the baby is in pain.‚Äù Anderson is a mother of four who got the idea for the app after noticing the variations of cries in her own children. She then collected a database of more than 2,000 infant cries and used machine learning to build the algorithms used in the app. ‚ÄúCurrent technology will alert parents when there is a sound coming from a child, but it doesn‚Äôt distinguish what type of sound it is,‚Äù said Anderson. ‚ÄúThis categorizes the cries to tell parents whether the baby is hungry or fussy or, with more than 90 percent accuracy, can determine if a baby is crying because it‚Äôs in pain‚Äù
tags: ChatterBaby app,babies‚Äô cries,deaf and hearing-impaired parents,UCLA Semel Institute,baby is fussy,the baby is in pain,infant cries

videoTitle: Joey: Laker For A Day l Team UCLA Lakers
videoDescription: Wrapped in bandages, Joey Paulk woke up at a military hospital more than two weeks after he nearly burned to death in Afghanistan. He saw his mother crying by his bedside, then began asking questions. ‚ÄúMy mom, she kind of leaned over. I said, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs wrong with my hands?‚Äô‚Äù He recalls. ‚ÄúShe said, ‚ÄòWell, they had to amputate your fingers.‚Äô I said, ‚ÄòWell, how many?‚Äô She said, ‚ÄòAll of them.‚Äô‚Äù Paulk also sustained severe burns, deforming many of his facial features. Other wounds were not as visible. But Paulk persevered, and the strength he showed in his recovery earned the former Army specialist UCLA Health Laker for a Day honors for the game against the Utah Jazz on April 8. Paulk‚Äôs injuries occurred July 5, 2007, when the tactical vehicle he was in drove over a mine. The vehicle flipped over and the fuel tank ignited, killing his team leader, ejecting Paulk and engulfing him in flames. By the time Paulk regained consciousness at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio, Texas, he could barely recognize himself. His lower left eyelid drooped. His upper left eyelid and nostrils were gone. His upper lip melted upward, and his lower lip turned inside out. Both of his ears were partially amputated. ‚ÄúAt first, I didn‚Äôt really understand what happened or how badly injured I was,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really feel any pain. And then slowly but surely, it started kicking in. And then I really kind of knew that I was in trouble.‚Äù Paulk tried to blend back into society, which proved difficult. People would stare at his injuries. Children, not knowing any better, would make comments. Paulk eventually started wearing long sleeves and a hat to try to conceal himself. ‚ÄúI was really uncomfortable with it and I started isolating myself,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs when my family kind of stepped in and said you need to do something.‚Äù Paulk found his way to UCLA Operation Mend, which began in 2007 as a collaboration with the military and the Veterans Health Administration to provide free specialized care to wounded warriors and their families. He underwent cosmetic surgeries at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center that helped realign and restore his face ‚Äì and, in the process, his self-confidence. ‚ÄúThey helped me physically. That immediately helped me psychologically. I owe everything to them,‚Äù he says. Paulk is now retired and lives in his hometown of Oceanside, California. He was joined at the Lakers‚Äô game with his girlfriend Ashley. They received an up-close view of warmups and met Coach Luke Walton, and Paulk discovered he and Walton had a shared connection. Paulk bowls every week with Walton‚Äôs high school basketball coach. It‚Äôs one of several sports Paulk can partake in again. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just very excited to represent the military and represent Operation Mend,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBeing a Laker for a Day is a dream come true.‚Äù Learn more at uclahealth.org/Lakers #TeamUCLALakers

videoTitle: Ladies of the Lakers Dinner at UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital l Team UCLA Lakers
videoDescription: Wives and significant others of the Los Angeles Lakers players and coaching staff made a special visit to UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital to help brighten the day for families and patients. The group, known as the Ladies of the Lakers, served food to families as well as patients who were able to leave their rooms. The ladies also brought to-go boxes for families who wanted to eat in the room with their loved one. The food was provided by Petros restaurant. ‚ÄúWe wanted to do something to get the Ladies of the Lakers out into the community and give back,‚Äù says Desiree LeSassier, Player Relations Manager for the Lakers. The Ladies of the Lakers worked with Child Life Specialists to learn and understand what patients and their families experience at hospitals. Families sometimes go weeks or months without having dinners together while their child is at the hospital, often running to vending machines or making quick trips to the cafeteria, says Lisa Gronroos, Child Life Specialist at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. She stresses the importance to families of socializing and eating healthy, and the opportunity to do both is what made the visit from the Ladies of the Lakers so meaningful. ‚ÄúWhen I was talking to the wives here that came to bring the dinner, it almost brought tears to my eyes because sometimes the families are forgotten,‚Äù Gronroos says. Gary McKay, whose 8-month-old son was in the hospital for spinal surgery, appreciated the ladies‚Äô efforts to take his mind off a potentially stressful situation and provide a positive reprieve in his day. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really great that the Lakers have this kind of an event because all of the families here are in a situation where their kids are in the hospital here and some of them are feeling sad,‚Äù McKay says. ‚ÄúAnd this is the kind of thing that kind of lifts your spirits.‚Äù UCLA Health and the Lakers share a commitment to building a healthier and more engaged community, celebrating sports and competition and providing the support needed for an active lifestyle. Learn more at uclahealth.org/lakers #TeamUCLALakers

videoTitle: Gio: Laker For A Day I Team UCLA Lakers
videoDescription: View Photos Here! The epileptic seizures would come on so strong and so frequently ‚Äì as many as 40 an hour ‚Äì that Gio‚Äôs parents lived in ‚Äúabsolute fear‚Äù every time the attacks began. They worried constantly about the toll the seizures were taking on their 4-year-old son and wondered whether a cure would ever come. ‚ÄúWe would ask him, ‚ÄòWhat are you feeling?‚Äô And he described it as being electrocuted,‚Äù says Ronnie, Gio‚Äôs father. What gave them comfort was the resilience and fortitude Gio often showed. He would tell his father: ‚ÄúI have epilepsy, I‚Äôm not epilepsy.‚Äù That uplifting attitude guided Gio and his family throughout their journey and earned him UCLA Health Laker for a Day honors for the game against the Miami Heat on March 16. After a series of tests in 2015, UCLA pediatric neurologist Raman Sankar discovered Gio had developed a brain abnormality in utero known as cortical dysplasia. The abnormality was located in the left frontal lobe, an operable area of the brain that would not negatively affect cognitive function, speech or motor skills. A medication regimen provided two years without seizures for Gio before ending in ‚Äúabrupt chaos,‚Äù Ronnie recalls, as the seizures returned to as many as 25 per day. The family had hoped to avoid surgery but made the difficult decision, in consultation with Dr. Sankar and the UCLA team, to pursue a procedure that would remove a portion of Gio‚Äôs brain. UCLA pediatric neurosurgeon Aria Fallah performed the seven-hour surgery at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. Gio emerged from the operating room and said, ‚ÄúI love you mommy and daddy.‚Äù Four days later, the family was back home in Las Vegas with a seizure-free Gio. Gio, along with his father, mother Marie, three brothers and a family friend, returned to Los Angeles to watch the Lakers. They were treated to a behind-the-scenes tour and a VIP experience, including an in-game video montage of Gio‚Äôs journey that seemed surreal to his parents. ‚ÄúWhen you have epilepsy, you feel a constant sense of dread that something is going to break through,‚Äù Ronnie says. ‚ÄúSo a year later, to be a Laker for a Day and see him on a jumbotron, it‚Äôs unimaginable for me. I would love to think that he will look back and be like, ‚ÄòI can share my story and hopefully it will improve the lives of other people.‚Äô‚Äù For more information about pediatric epilepsy treatment, visit uclahealth.org/mattel/pediatric-neurology
caption: false

videoTitle: Kid Captain Rebecca | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Rebecca was a perfectly healthy toddler. Then, suddenly, she began having uncontrollable seizures ‚Äì as many as 80 per day. ‚ÄúPicture not even being able to do anything with your child, not being able to hold a conversation or anything,‚Äù says her mother, Edwina. At just 3 years old, Rebecca was diagnosed with epilepsy and underwent brain surgery at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. She had a second surgery when she was 8. Rebecca, who performed ballet and tap dance, had to relearn the most basic activities. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd struggle because I had to learn to walk and talk again,‚Äù she says. Rebecca, now 15, is able to enjoy her favorite hobbies, including painting, writing poetry, listening to music, reading action fantasy books, crocheting, running independent service projects, hanging out with friends, boogie boarding and dancing. She also has excelled in the classroom, earning acceptance into the National Junior Honor Society and National Honor Society. Rebecca hopes to spread more awareness about epilepsy and attend college. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very grateful to be selected Kid Captain,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúTo bring awareness to epilepsy and to educate others, it‚Äôs a big deal. Out of all the opportunities I‚Äôve had in my lifetime, it‚Äôs the biggest one.‚Äù Learn more about UCLA Kid Captains at https://www.uclahealth.org/mattel/kid-captain
caption: false

videoTitle: Kid Captain Summer | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Summer never let the pain stop her from caring about others or enjoying her favorite activities, especially drawing and playing with her brother. It‚Äôs just her nature to put other people first. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs always concerned about others, more concerned about others than she is herself,‚Äù says her mother, Tene. For a while, though, everyone was concerned for Summer. She was diagnosed with onset of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, which causes painful joint swelling (inflammation) and stiffness. Summer would have prolonged periods of pain that drained her energy and kept from enjoying her usual day-to-day activities. ‚ÄúI just remember being really tired and not wanting to get out of bed,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know if I was going to die or if I was going to not be able to walk again because I was in so much pain.‚Äù The painful flare-ups also left her parents exhausted and searching for answers. ‚ÄúI had no words, because I didn‚Äôt know what to do,‚Äù says her father, John. ‚ÄúAs a parent, I felt like totally helpless at the time.‚Äù Summer‚Äôs parents decided to have her care transferred to UCLA because a doctor who was instrumental in diagnosing Summer had just finished a rotation at UCLA and raved about the treatment she would receive. Her heath has improved ever since. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a total change in Summer since we‚Äôve been at UCLA,‚Äù her father says. ‚ÄúAnd as a parent, I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòYay! Finally, yes, I can see light at the end of the tunnel.‚Äô‚Äù Summer was honored and excited to be a UCLA Kid Captain. She hopes her role can inspire others during difficult times. ‚ÄúBeing Kid Captain is a big thing for me,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBecause I can show people that I‚Äôm a leader, that your disease or your illness doesn‚Äôt discriminate you and that everybody, any size or age, can be a leader.‚Äù

videoTitle: Richard's Story - SSCD | UCLA Health News
videoDescription: Out of the blue, Richard Barron, 48, woke up deaf in one ear. The University of Maine women‚Äôs basketball coach was ultra-sensitive to noise--the sound of someone loading the dishwasher was excruciating. Even stranger, Richard began hearing his bones creak and his eyelids move. Far worse was the noise-related brain fog that descended on him inside the raucous basketball gym. He‚Äôd call a timeout during a game‚Äîonly to hear the ref blow a whistle or the band strike up a tune--and forget why he called the timeout. After his condition forced him on medical leave, Richard retreated to bed, and his wife and three children took turns tip-toing upstairs to share their day in whispers. Over a period of five months, Richard visited three prestigious medical centers and saw 15 doctors. No one knew what was wrong. Finally, a CT scan of his skull revealed a tiny opening in his ear bone and an audiologist diagnosed him with superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD). Researching SSCD online, Richard found a webinar by a UCLA Health neurosurgeon. Dr. Isaac Yang offered to review Richard‚Äôs records electronically and confirmed the SSCD diagnosis. Drawn to the minimally invasive approach that Yang pioneered with UCLA ear surgeon Dr. Quinton Gopen, Richard flew across the country for surgery at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center. In the operating room, Yang made a small incision in Richard‚Äôs skull and pushed his brain out of the way, allowing Gopen to plug the miniscule hole in his ear. When Richard awoke, he was ecstatic to realize that the bizarre noises in his head had vanished and his hearing had returned. That night, his wife and he celebrated over dinner in a Los Angeles restaurant. Gopen and Yang say Richard‚Äôs frustrating journey toward diagnosis isn‚Äôt unusual. Superior canal dehiscence wasn‚Äôt identified until 1998 ‚Äì a recent enough discovery only now being added to textbooks and taught in medical school. As a result, most physicians are not familiar with the rare syndrome, which affects an estimated 1% of the population. Learn more about the Semicircular Canal Dehiscence at http://neurosurgery.ucla.edu/semicircular-canal-dehiscence

videoTitle: Dana & Brian: Laker for a Day | Team UCLA Lakers
videoDescription: His father‚Äôs failing health weighed on his mind every day. Brian, a shoe salesman at Nordstrom‚Äôs, had been watching his dad, Dana, 69, slowly deteriorate from end stage kidney disease for more than two years. His father endured daily, 12-hour dialysis treatments while he waited for a kidney donation. ‚ÄúWatching my dad go through this was not easy,‚Äù said Brian, 48, who lives in the city of Westminster in Orange County. ‚ÄúHe was always a strong guy and we were watching him lose his drive through all of it.‚Äù Brian and his wife, Roxie, started seriously discussing the idea of Brian donating a kidney to his dad. ‚ÄúI was thankful that he wanted to donate his kidney but I was mindful of what that might do to him,‚Äù Dana said. ‚ÄúBut he was very plain about what he wanted to do.‚Äù Once Brian made the decision to donate, he said he noticed little signs reinforcing his choice starting popping up ‚Äîa reference to kidney donation on a TV show, something he heard on the radio, a news story about a surgeon donating to a colleague. Then came the biggest sign. An avid Los Angeles Lakers fan, Brian always watched the team‚Äôs social media feeds. He was casually scrolling his Facebook page when he saw a video about a woman named Dawn, who was being recognized as a Laker for a Day in February 2017 by the team and its health partner, UCLA Health, for donating her kidney to a stranger. Read and see more at uclahealth.org/lakers

videoTitle: UCLA CAR T-Cell Therapy | UCLA Health
videoDescription: With CAR-T, the medical team gathers a patient's T cells, which play a central role in the immune response. They then modify those cells to target lymphoma and leukemia and reinfuse them into the patient. Recently, a CAR-T treatment for leukemia became the first gene therapy approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Here is one UCLA patient's story. Learn more: https://www.uclahealth.org/car-t-cell-therapy

videoTitle: Philip H. Cohen, MD - Internal Medicine | UCLA Health Encino - Primary & Specialty Care
videoDescription: Dr. Cohen grew up in New Jersey as an avid Mets fan. He graduated Cum Laude from Yale University in 1991, with Special Distinction in Psychology. He then returned to New Jersey, where he graduated from Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School. He completed his residency in Internal Medicine at Wake Forest University, after which he completed his fellowship in Primary Care Sports Medicine at UCLA. Dr. Cohen served for 10 years as the Assistant Team Physician for Rutgers University Sports Medicine, while also serving as an attending internist and primary care physician for Rutgers Health Services. Dr. Cohen is an Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine at the David Geffen School of Medicine, and is Board Certified in Internal Medicine and Sports Medicine. Learn more about Dr. Philip Cohen at https://www.uclahealth.org/philip-cohen

videoTitle: Kid Captain Nathan | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: If 13-year-old Nathan has some free time, you can be sure to find him on a basketball court or watching his favorite team, the Golden State Warriors, play on TV. Nathan has loved playing basketball from a very young age, but he has also faced a serious neurological disorder for most of his life. When Nathan was 5 years old, his father passed away from epilepsy, a condition that Nathan would be diagnosed with just one year later. For several years, Nathan received medications for sudden and unpredictable seizures, but they were not working as well as hoped. In search of a more effective treatment, Nathan‚Äôs mother Johana sought help from epilepsy experts at UCLA. After being evaluated by UCLA pediatric neurosurgeons, it was determined that Nathan was a candidate for epilepsy surgery ‚Äì a procedure that would remove the area of his brain connected to his seizures. In March 2017, Nathan underwent a successful surgery and through the process became a devoted UCLA Bruins Basketball fan. Nathan has been selected as UCLA Kid Captain for his bravery and deep love of sports. ‚ÄúNathan being Kid Captain means a lot because I know how much he loves basketball and this is a big opportunity for him to express himself and go out and enjoy it,‚Äù Gongora says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably a once-in-a-lifetime experience for him.‚Äù
caption: false

videoTitle: Kid Captain Helena | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Helena is an active, energetic and enthusiastic young girl with a kind heart. Following stomach surgery, Helena asked only for art supplies on her 9th birthday ‚Äì and promptly donated it all to UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. ‚ÄúThey were so nice to me that I wanted to give something back,‚Äù she says. A year earlier, Helena developed appendicitis and had her appendix removed. But five months later, she was experiencing severe stomach pain and came via ambulance to UCLA. ‚ÄúIt was in my stomach and it hurt really bad. I had to get in my bed and curl up in a ball,‚Äù Helena says. Doctors performed emergency abdominal surgery to remove a bowel obstruction, and Helena emerged from the procedure pain-free. She returned to UCLA again five months later, and although she didn‚Äôt need surgery this time, she spent a few days in the hospital for additional tests and recovery. During both her stays at UCLA, Helena enjoyed drawing, painting and playing games with the staff. Not only did her time at the hospital inspire Helena‚Äôs thoughtful birthday donation, she now wants to be a doctor when she grows up. Congratulations to Helena on being recognized as a Kid Captain! UCLA is honored to care for Helena and her family.
tags: UCLA Kid Captain,UCLA Mattel Childrens Hospital,Athletics
caption: false

videoTitle: Kid Captain Evan | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Doctors diagnosed Evan with a non-functioning bladder, kidney failure and incomplete development of his lungs before he was even born, delivering the difficult news to his parents that he may not be able to survive. ‚ÄúEvery day since has been a blessing,‚Äù says his mother, Alison. Evan has received two kidney transplants ‚Äì one from his mother and another from her cousin ‚Äì at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. Now he is so upbeat and active that ‚Äúsometimes you forget that he‚Äôs fragile because he‚Äôs pretty rough and tumble and at it,‚Äù says his father, Daniel. Adds Alison: ‚ÄúEvan has been the brightest light in my life. He‚Äôs very smart, witty, really positive. He doesn‚Äôt seem to have anything to hold him back. He‚Äôs just really persevering and friendly. He wants to talk to everybody. He‚Äôs just a rad kid.‚Äù Evan enjoys spending time in the hospital‚Äôs play areas, where he always wants to stay and talk to others. His favorite sport is basketball. ‚ÄúBeing captain for a day is going to be great. Go UCLA!‚Äù Evan says. UCLA is inspired and honored by the opportunity to treat and care for Evan and his family. Congratulations to Evan for being honored as a UCLA Kid Captain!

videoTitle: Kid Captain Zachary | UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital
videoDescription: Ten-year-old Zack Patterson loves to play hockey, lacrosse and soccer ‚Äì especially with his little sister Sam. Zack is a loving big brother, a son, an athlete, a student and a pediatric cancer survivor. In 2011, when Zack was 4, his parents started to notice bruising on his body and a lingering cough. After a trip to the UCLA Emergency Department, Zack was diagnosed with high-risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). During the first year of his diagnosis, Zack spent 200 days receiving care at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital. Over the course of three years, Zack underwent countless chemotherapy infusions, blood draws, imaging scans and medical procedures.¬† ‚ÄúThe most interesting thing about that time is that if you ask Zack about his experience at the hospital, he doesn‚Äôt have anything negative to say,‚Äù Zack‚Äôs mother Kristen says. ‚ÄúHe remembers the playroom, the animal stickers on the third floor and most of all, the people who cared for him.‚Äù¬† Zack completed his treatment regimen in 2014 and is now in remission! Zack and his family have since joined our UCLA Pediatric Survivorship Clinic and continue to find ways to support others going through similar experiences. Kristen sits on the Parent Advisory Council at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital, where she works with other parents to create an advocacy platform for our pediatric patients and families.¬† Congratulations to Zack and his family, whose courage and optimism are an inspiration to us all! Learn more about UCLA Kid Captains at https://www.uclahealth.org/mattel/kid-captain
tags: UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital,UCLA Pediatric Survivorship Clinic,Parent Advisory Council at UCLA Mattel Children‚Äôs Hospital
